1. General Provisions 1.1 Scope of Application (1) Ground instrumentation during construction includes the installation, measurement, and data management of instruments for safety management in the following construction projects: soft ground works, slope excavation works, foundation works, water and sewage works, tunnel works, dam works, river levee works, port works, building construction, underground excavation works, blasting vibration-inducing works, and temporary shoring works. (2) Instrumentation for purposes other than those specified in (1) shall be planned separately. 1.2 Reference Standards 1. No relevant legal provisions for 2.1. 1. 2.2 Related Standards. KDS 11 10 15 Ground Measurement 1.3 Definitions: None Submission 1.4 1. 4.1 Pre-Contract Submission Documents (1) System General Specifications and Description ① Must be written to ensure consistency with the technical specifications of each item in this standard. (2) Supply Material List and Material Specifications ① Manufacturer's Calibration Equipment Certification ② Product Inspection or Calibration Certificate ③ Catalog ④ Warranty Certificate ⑤ Quality Certification Certificate ⑥ Availability of Products and Sub-Materials (3) Comprehensive Process Plan Including Design, Manufacturing, and Testing Plan (4) Equipment Supply Record (5) Technical Data and Drawings (6) Detailed Methods, Guidelines, and Drawings for Installation 1. 4.2 Documents to be Submitted after Contract (1) Manufacturing Process Flow ① A detailed step-by-step process flow covering all aspects of the contract, including design, manufacturing, assembly, testing, and training. (2) Manufacturing Equipment Specifications ① Type and specifications ② Drawings and structure ③ Manufacturing special features and characteristics ④ Standard drawings ⑤ Other required items (3) Installation and Construction Data ① Inter-equipment connections and supply cable details ② Equipment installation environment conditions (4) Client-Provided Data ① Materials required for system design and manufacturing. 1. 4.3 Submission Documents After Installation of Measuring Instruments (1) The instrument responsible person shall submit the operation manual and the user manual after installing the measuring system. (2) The operation manual for each measuring instrument shall include at least the following items. ① Operating Theory a. Purpose of the instrument b. Basic measurement principle of the instrument c. Sketches and block diagrams illustrating typical applications d. Measurement range of the system e. Installation instructions ② Operating and Measurement Procedures a. Detailed procedures for equipment preparation and commencement of measurement b. Precautions related to users and equipment c. Method for obtaining initial values after instrument installation d. Procedure for obtaining subsequent measurements after initial values e. Construction and environmental conditions that must be recorded for each measurement to be used for cause and effect analysis of measurement values f. List of tools and supplies required for measurement g. On-site data recording sheet h. Sample of completed on-site data recording sheet i. Items to be recorded during the installation period required for subsequent measurement data analysis ③ Maintenance and Maintenance a. Matters regarding storage in the field condition b. Timing and method for equipment replacement c. On-site inspection items d. Recommended list of spare parts including consumables e. Total list of tools, spare parts, and supplies required during maintenance 2. Material Contents: None 3. Construction 3.1 Soft Ground Works 3. General Provisions 3. 1. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of application of ground measurement during the construction of soft ground works shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. "1.1 shall apply. (2) Measurement management for purposes other than those specified in (1) shall be handled separately." 3. 1.2 Materials 3. 1. 2.1 Types of Instrumentation (1) Inclinometers are applied when the ground is weak and ground displacement is anticipated, or when important structures are within the range affected by construction. The measurement error limit of the instrumentation is ± It shall be within 1.0mm. (2) A groundwater level meter shall be applied when changes in groundwater are anticipated and the groundwater level needs to be reflected in the analysis of measurement results. (3) For surface settlement plates, the measurement error limit of the instrument is ±. "1.0mm 이내이어야 한다.(4) 층별침하계(extensometer)는 연약지반 굴착공사와 인접하여 중요한 구조물이 매설된 경우에 적용하고, 공학적 특성이 다른 다층지반의 침하량을 측정할 경우에 적용한다. 계측기기의 측정오차 한계는 ±" It shall be within 1.0mm (5). The measurement range of the water pressure in the clearance shall be planned considering the design operating water pressure in the clearance, and it should be able to measure at least 1 MPa. 3. 1.3 Construction 3. 1. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) Instrumentation shall be installed at the locations designated in the design, but considering the need for it to be installed prior to construction and utilized for construction management, the installation location may be modified or added after consultation with the site supervisor if necessary. (2) Common Requirements for Instrumentation Installation ① When performing drilling work for instrumentation installation, casing shall be installed entirely. The inner diameter of the drilled hole shall be 86mm or greater. ② The drilling equipment shall be adjustable within 1° on the X, Y, and Z axes to allow for parallel installation with the ground, and shall use equipment capable of maintaining verticality within 1° during drilling operations. In addition, prior approval of the site supervisor shall be obtained for the equipment's performance. ③ The location of instrumentation installation shall be surveyed before drilling, and the survey results and locations of ground investigation and instrumentation installation shall be indicated on a drawing and approved by the site supervisor. This drawing and survey results shall be preserved and managed to prevent damage. ④ The sand used to fill the boreholes for piezometers and groundwater level gauges shall be No.200 sieve. Sand with a permeability of 5% or less passing through 0.08mm shall be used.⑤ The pore size specification of the filter wrapping the piezometric tip shall be 80μm or less.⑥ The grain size of the sand placed in the filter wrapping the piezometric tip shall be 80μm or more.⑦ The upper 1m of the instrumentation where the sand is introduced into the borehole as a filter material shall be filled with bentonite pellets to prevent the mixing of bentonite-cement mix with the sand during grouting, and the bentonite-cement mixing ratio shall be determined by trial mixing under the supervision of the construction supervisor to match the strength and deformation modulus of the surrounding ground, and the trial mixing results shall be submitted.⑧ The grouting equipment’s grouting discharge pressure... the upper surface" 0.4m× 0.4m, lower surface 1.0m× 1.0m, depth 1. Excavate 0.3m deep and backfill with protective concrete after installing a protective box at a depth of 20cm in the concrete, then cure and install the instrumentation PAD and protective box. ⑪ Measure the initial value. (6) Piezometer ① Install the borehole with an inner diameter of 86mm to 116mm using a rotating reamer until the planned depth, while drilling and avoiding the use of a crawler drill. ② After removing the borehole casing near the location where the piezometer tip will be installed, thoroughly clean with clear water to remove any slime, and do not use air to clean. ③ Fill more than 20cm of sand below the piezometer tip. ④ Connect a plummet to a measuring tape to verify the drilling depth. ⑤ Saturate the piezometer tip with water for 24 hours to remove air bubbles, and read and record the initial value according to the method specified in the instrument catalog. ⑥ After confirming the functionality and specified accuracy of the instrument by inserting the saturated piezometer into the test borehole, transport the piezometer tip, which is still submerged in water, to the site in a saturated package or filter bag and install the piezometer at the specified depth. ⑦ Fill more than 20cm of sand above the piezometer and compact it to form a permeable layer. ⑧ Remove the casing by about 1m and, to prevent the infiltration of bentonite grout into the sand layer, place a 100cm thick bentonite pellet on top of the sand layer and compact it to form a bentonite plug. ⑨ Remove the casing while using a grouting hose to perform cement-bentonite grouting to form an impermeable layer to the ground surface (sand mat layer). The mixing ratio of bentonite and cement shall be determined by a test mix to match the strength and deformation coefficient of the surrounding ground. After the grout has cured, refill any settlement with grout material. ⑩ While performing grouting, provide snaking to the cables in the ground and on the ground surface to prevent cable disconnection due to ground deformation, and also insert a protective pipe more than 1m into the borehole to prevent cable disconnection. ⑪ Measure the initial value after the grouting agent has cured and at least 72 hours have passed since the bentonite pellets were placed.⑫ To protect the cable from soil backfill, snake the cable on the ground surface and place it in a protective pipe to prevent damage to the cable from the soil backfill operation. (7) Layer Settlement Gauge ① Drill to the support layer while installing the installation borehole casing with an inner diameter of 86mm to 116mm. ② After drilling, thoroughly clean with clear water to completely remove slime. ③ Connect a plummet to a measuring tape to verify the drilling depth. ④ The end of the initially inserted casing should be capped to prevent foreign material from entering the casing. ⑤ In the field office, pre-arrange the casing and coupling combination in advance, considering the horizontal and vertical deformation amounts, to match the drilling depth. Also, rivet several casings and couplings together, wrap them with rubber tape, mark the number on each connected casing, attach a magnetic sensor at the planned installation depth, receive inspection from the construction supervisor, and then transport them to the site to assemble the connected casings into the installation borehole and insert them into the drilled hole along with the grouting hose, performing riveting and sealing at the connections while installing the casing to the support layer. ⑥ The datum magnet is attached at the bottom, the spider magnet is attached at each measurement point, and a flexible string is used to connect them to the top, and a plate magnet is attached to the ground surface. However, the spider magnet may be installed just below the telescopic coupling to consider the potential settlement in that layer. ⑦ The telescopic (telescopic) coupling’s amount of expansion is based on the design settlement amount for each layer. It shall be 1.5 to 2 times or more and arranged considering the interlayer compression characteristics.⑧ Remove the casing up to the installation point of the settlement gauge measuring device on each floor and remove the string connected to the spider magnet to fix it in the borehole.⑨ Matters related to cement bentonite grouting shall be in accordance with this standard. 3. 1. Follow 3.1(6)⑨.⑩ Repeat the operations of ⑧ and ⑨ above to complete magnetic installation and grouting at each point, then remove the hose.⑪ Measure the initial values. 3. 1. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any anomalies and calibrate if necessary. 3. 1. 3.3 Protection of Instrumentation (1) To prevent instrument malfunctions such as damage and operational failure caused by settlement or backfilling work after instrument installation, a protective fence shall be installed, and a sign shall be posted in a visible location. (2) The protective fence shall be arranged in a rectangular shape centered on the instrument, and each protective fence shall be secured with thick wire or the like to prevent movement. (3) The person responsible for the maintenance and management of the instrument and protective fence shall be the responsible technical personnel for the project, and their affiliation, name, and contact information shall be attached to the fence for management. (4) In the event of instrument damage due to external factors, it shall be reported to the construction supervisor immediately and then reinstalled. (5) All losses of instruments due to construction or management negligence shall be reinstalled at the contractor's expense. 3. 1. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Cables for transmitting measurement data shall be selected in a format suitable for continuous measurement, and installation plans including cable laying, communication standards, and cable connection and termination shall be established. (2) Measurement instrument cables shall use dedicated measurement instrument cables, and shall be configured as a single run from the buried point to the measurement room without any connection points during installation. (3) Wiring shall be done with sufficient slack to prevent tensile stress on the cable due to settlement of the measurement instruments. (4) All wiring of measurement instruments shall be protected by installing measurement-dedicated conduits. (5) The cross-sectional area of measurement-dedicated conduits shall not exceed 32% of the cable's cross-sectional area. (6) Measurement-dedicated conduits shall use measurement-dedicated cables exclusively. However, other cables that do not interfere with the communication of the measurement-dedicated cables may be used jointly upon confirmation by the construction supervisor. (7) The ends of the cables shall be waterproofed to prevent water penetration during measurement and maintenance. (8) The ends of the cables shall be marked with the type, number, and type of wire of the measurement instrument to prevent confusion. (9) All data transmission equipment shall consider compatibility when selecting transmission equipment in preparation for future expansion and scalability, in the event that the measurement system is operated. 3. 1. 3.5 Inspection and Testing Following Installation of Measurement System (1) The inspection conducted upon on-site delivery shall be performed for all equipment, accompanied by a test report issued by an accredited agency. However, the test report from the manufacturer may be substituted if approved by the client. (2) Measurement instruments shall be subjected to equipment testing, including instrument checks and initial value measurements, before use. 3. 1. 3.6 Instrumentation Management (1) To facilitate on-site analysis of measurement results, relevant equipment and systems shall be installed within the on-site office. (2) Instrumentation shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to maintain performance and ensure the reliability of measurement results. (3) Instrumentation shall be installed as specified in the specifications to prevent malfunctions and errors, and defective instrumentation shall be replaced immediately at the contractor's expense. (4) To protect instrumentation from vehicles and equipment, an instrumentation protection fence shall be installed and maintained around the instrumentation, and field workers shall be notified. When backfilling around the instrumentation, a designated technical staff member shall be present on-site to supervise the manual placement of the backfill. If damage to the instrumentation occurs due to negligence, it shall be repaired immediately at the contractor's expense. 3. 1. 3.7 Instrumentation (1) General Provisions ① The instrumentation equipment to be used on-site shall be selected and procured based on site conditions and intended use, and the specifications of all equipment shall be submitted to and approved by the Site Supervisor before purchase and installation. ② The selection, procurement, installation, and measurement of instrumentation equipment related to instrumentation management shall be performed by an instrumentation management specialist or a professional with equivalent or greater capabilities. ③ The initial readings of all instrumentation equipment shall be taken under the supervision of the Site Supervisor, immediately recorded, and submitted to the Site Supervisor for verification. The Site Supervisor shall verify them accordingly. ④ Level surveys shall be primarily performed using a level instrument; however, indirect level surveys using an optical instrument may be conducted if site conditions necessitate it. Also, surveying instruments used for the work shall be of equal or better performance than specified, and their performance shall be pre-approved by the Site Supervisor. ⑤ Level surveys shall be performed each time the initial readings of all installed instrumentation equipment (settlement plates, piezometers, small element installation depths, etc.) are measured, and all measurement values shall be recorded and managed as EL (elevation). ⑥ The Contractor shall maintain and manage all instrumentation data records, and measurement values shall be submitted to the Site Supervisor. Measurement results shall only be recognized as valid if the measurement values are approved by the Site Supervisor based on their performance. (2) Surface Settlement Plates ① Immediately upon commencement of work, refer to the instrumentation layout drawing and install temporary bench marks (T.B.M.) firmly and immovably in stable ground outside the project site at intervals of no more than 500m. Perform a reciprocal level survey from the first-order benchmark located within the project site in accordance with the first-order leveling standard to calculate the elevation of the T.B.M. and use this as the leveling reference point for this work. ② Establish a settlement plate management area based on the installed T.B.M. ③ Measurements shall be performed by leveling the difference in elevation between the T.B.M. and the top of the rod connected to the settlement plate. ④ Settlement shall be calculated as the difference between the initial elevation (Elevation, hereinafter E.L.) and the measured E.L. ⑤ Each settlement plate leveling survey shall be performed within the management area and closed upon the corresponding T.B.M. to verify the accuracy of the survey, correct any errors, and the instrumentation results shall be verified by preparing and reviewing survey field books and settlement management logs. ⑥ After each measurement is completed, plot the measured settlement on a time-settlement relationship graph to check for any abnormalities. If any abnormalities are detected, remeasure immediately to prevent inaccurate measurements. ⑦ During each settlement plate leveling survey, simultaneously measure the ground surface above the embankment and check the condition of adjacent embankments to be utilized for analysis and back-interpretation of instrumentation data. (3) Groundwater Level Meters ① The initial groundwater level of the original ground before backfilling shall be used as the groundwater level measured in the exploratory borehole investigation or the borehole investigation during the installation stage. ② Measure and submit initial readings and measurement values to the Site Supervisor for verification. ③ Calculate the measurement values as EL using the level of the settlement column of the surface settlement plate and the length of the casing of the groundwater level meter. ④ For groundwater level meters installed outside the project area, perform level surveys of the casing top at regular intervals to verify any settlement of the casing. (4) Inclinometers ① The measurement direction shall be marked on the label and maintained consistently, and the measurement shall be performed from the bottom of the casing upwards. Measurements shall be taken every 0.5m, including both A and B directions, and the resultant vector shall be indicated. ② Initial values and measured values shall be recorded and submitted to the site supervisor for review and approval. (5) Piezometer① Measurements shall not be performed within a radius of twice the depth of the weak layer in the vicinity of the piezometer installation area if earthwork is in progress or heavy equipment is present. ② Initial values and measured values shall be recorded and submitted to the site supervisor for review and approval. ③ Measured values shall be corrected for groundwater level fluctuations. ④ Temperature shall be obtained from the measured values of each instrument. ⑤ Calibration shall be performed automatically by the analysis S/W. ⑥ The change in the burial depth of the piezometer due to subsidence shall be calculated based on the measured values of the layer-by-layer settlement sensor, and the measured values shall be corrected accordingly. (6) Layer-by-layer Settlement Gauge① The measurement method involves measuring relative displacements in sequence from datum magnetic to spider magnetic, and then to plate magnetic. ② The measurement unit shall be in mm. ③ Initial values and measured values shall be recorded and submitted to the site supervisor for review and approval. 3. 1. 3.8 Measurement frequency (1) Measurement is in table. Measurements shall be performed at the predetermined frequency based on the measurement frequency and period, as referenced in 3.1-1, and measurement results shall be reported promptly according to the planned schedule. (2) The frequency of measurements shall be based on the design drawings and specifications, but may be adjusted according to site conditions and circumstances.표 3.1-1 Instrumentation Frequency for Soft Ground 		Instrumentation			After Completion of Soil Embankment	Within 1 Month			1～3 Months			After 3 Months			Remarks			Inclinometer			Once a day			Once a week			Once every two weeks			Manual Measurement			Groundwater Level Meter			Once a day			Once a week			Once every two weeks			Manual Measurement			Ground Surface Settlement Plate			Once a day			Once a week			Once every two weeks			Manual Measurement			Layer-by-Layer Settlement Meter			Once a day			Once a week			Once every two weeks			Manual Measurement			Pore Water Pressure Meter			Once a day			Once a week			Once every two weeks			Manual Measurement			Note 1) The above measurement frequencies are based on manual measurement and can be adjusted and performed according to the occurrence of risks – convergence of deformation, changes in deformation amount, other field conditions, and can be converted to automatic measurement depending on the section characteristics. (3) Measurement items and frequencies may be adjusted after consideration of site conditions and ground conditions and upon confirmation by the construction supervisor. 3. 1. 3.9 Instrumentation Period (1) The termination of instrumentation management shall be determined by prior consultation with the site supervisor based on the data analyzed by a top-tier technical expert in soil engineering, taking into account the site conditions. 3. 1. 3.10 Analysis and Summary of Measurement Results (1) Performance analysis and other records related to measurements shall be conducted by qualified technical personnel with expertise equivalent to or exceeding that of a Senior Specialist in Geotechnical Engineering. (2) The measurement results shall be analyzed by a Senior Specialist in Geotechnical Engineering and the analyzed data shall be submitted to the site supervisor to maximize efforts to prevent issues related to constructability and verification of construction quantities. (3) During construction, various measurements shall be systematically performed, and the measurement results shall be reflected in the design and construction. The design details from the initial plan should be modified as necessary to be more suitable for the site conditions, and the work shall be managed to improve safety, economy, and constructability. (4) Measurement results should be organized and recorded in a manner that allows them to be utilized for routine construction management and incorporated into future plans. (5) Based on the results of the subsurface investigation and field data, time factors, consolidation coefficients, compression indices, and ground strength changes shall be calculated for each unit management area and at each completion stage. These values shall be compared with the planned schedule in the earthwork construction design, and back analysis shall be performed to establish measures such as modifications to the loading earthwork plan and changes to the retention period, which are then fed back into the construction process. In this case, the feasibility of back analysis shall be determined through consultation between the field engineer and the site supervisor, considering the site conditions. (6) The measurement results from inclinometers shall be analyzed by presenting the changes in measured values over time at each measurement depth as a graph, along with the management criteria based on the earthwork height at the time of measurement. (7) Whether the anticipated consolidation acceleration effect is achieved after ground improvement and earthwork loading shall be reviewed. If the actual results differ from the anticipated results, the causes shall be investigated and analyzed, and measures shall be established. (8) In areas where the depth of the soft ground changes rapidly, the differential settlement caused by the difference in residual settlement shall be calculated and analyzed for its impact on structures and underground utilities, and managed accordingly. 3. 1. 3.11 Instrumentation Management Standard (1) Monitoring points for stability management shall be monitored and analyzed daily for detailed measurements of ground deformation and deformation rate, as well as settlement and settlement rate, during and within 7 days after embankment completion, to ensure construction proceeds in a stable state. (2) Due to the simplification of complex soil layer configurations and the application of representative soil parameters during the design of soft ground, discrepancies often arise between the design settlement and the measured settlement. Therefore, regardless of consolidation theory, a curve-fitting equation suitable for the measured settlement curve should be derived to estimate future settlement, and the initial design should be reviewed. If there is a discrepancy between the measured and design settlement, it should be reflected in both construction and design. 3. 1. 3.12 Measurement Result Reporting (1) The measurement personnel shall promptly report the measurement results daily after performing the measurement. (2) Weekly reports shall include graphs and summaries of the measured data’s deformation, changes in amount, rate of change, and location. (3) Monthly reports shall include graphs and summaries of the measured data’s deformation, changes in amount, rate of change, and location, along with a comparison analysis against established standards. (4) In cases of significant displacement or when urgent action is required due to site conditions, ad hoc reports shall be submitted to allow for appropriate response. (5) Upon completion of the measurement of the target facility, all measurement records and performance analysis data collected during the construction period shall be compiled and submitted to the construction supervisor. 3. 1. "3.13 Submission (1) The submission is based on this standard." Referring to 1.4, you shall submit the necessary documents after consulting with the construction supervisor. 3.2 Slope Excavation Work 3. 2.1 General Provisions 3. 2. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of ground measurement during excavation work for slopes shall be in accordance with Section 1, General Provisions of this standard. Follow 1.1. (2) Instrumentation for the protection of rear structures during the construction of cut slopes shall comply with the instrumentation specifications for excavation work. (3) Instrumentation management for purposes other than those mentioned in (1) and (2) shall be planned separately. 3. 2.2 Materials 3. 2. 2.1 Instrumentation (1) Surveying instruments for measuring surface displacement, tilt, and cracks (strain gauges, GPS) are installed to confirm the surface displacement of the slope. The accuracy shall be based on ±1mm. (2) Inclinometers are installed to confirm subsurface displacement caused by slope movement. A borehole investigation shall be performed to obtain soil properties data when drilling, and the instruments shall be installed in the borehole. The accuracy shall be based on ±1mm. (3) Piezometers are installed to confirm natural water level displacement of the slope. The accuracy shall be based on ±1cm, and a filter with approximately twice the permeability coefficient of the corresponding slope shall be incorporated. (4) Pore water pressure gauges are installed to confirm the pore water pressure displacement within the ground due to rainfall and groundwater level fluctuations of the slope. Pore water pressure displacement... It shall be able to measure with an accuracy of 0.1MPa or higher.(5) The rain gauge shall be installed on the ground surface of the slope for the acquisition of rainfall data of the slope rainfall. It shall measure rainfall with an accuracy of ±1mm or higher, be able to convert the amount of snow falling in winter into rainfall, and operate normally in cold temperatures. 3. 2. 2.2 Instrumentation Data Acquisition System (1) The instrumentation data acquisition system shall be selected, considering factors such as the characteristics of collapse and activity progression, the importance of slopes and slope facilities, potential impact of damage, cost-effectiveness, and measurement frequency. (2) To prevent or minimize damage caused by slope collapse and activity, it is important to detect early signs, and it is necessary to transmit and process information promptly along with monitoring. It is desirable to use automated technology that consistently handles the collection, processing, and interpretation of instrumentation data. 3. 2.3 Construction 3. 2. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) Instrumentation to be buried in the ground shall be installed using drilling equipment to minimize disturbance to the ground. (2) The reference point of the instrumentation installed by drilling shall be drilled to a stable stratum where displacement is deemed insignificant below the anticipated activity area. When measuring slope displacement, the reference point shall be installed in a location that is not affected by deformation of the slope. (3) Areas where displacement is anticipated during construction as a result of prior investigations shall be installed prior to construction. If installation of the instrumentation is difficult before the completion of slope construction due to the characteristics of the instrument, it shall be installed within 48-72 hours after the completion of the slope construction. 3. 2. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any anomalies and calibrate if necessary. 3. 2. 3.3 Protection of Measuring Instruments (1) The area surrounding installed measuring instruments shall be adequately protected to prevent adverse effects from weather and the growth of plants and animals, ensuring proper instrument management and accurate measurements. (2) Rain gauges should be installed in locations free from the influence of fallen leaves and other debris to ensure accurate measurement of rainfall at the installation point. 3. 2. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Due to the collapse characteristics of slopes, real-time monitoring is required for slope measurement, so cables for transmitting measurement data should be selected in a format suitable for continuous monitoring. (2) Instrument cables shall use dedicated cables from the instrument manufacturer, and shall be configured as a single run without any connection points from the buried location to the measurement room during installation. (3) Wiring for all instruments shall be protected by installing measurement-specific conduits. (4) Cable ends shall be waterproofed to prevent water penetration during measurement and maintenance. 3. 2. 3.5 Inspection and testing following the installation of the measurement system (1) Inspection and testing following the installation of the measurement system shall be in accordance with this standard. 3. 1. follows 3.5 3. 2. 3.6 Instrument Management (1) The area surrounding installed instruments shall be adequately protected to prevent adverse effects from weather and the growth of plants and animals, ensuring proper instrument management and measurement. A sign indicating the instrument name, location, initial measurement date, and initial measurement value shall be installed and maintained. (2) If an instrument is damaged due to weather, plant and animal growth, blasting, or other reasons, measurements shall continue after reinstalling an instrument adjacent to the damaged one. 3. 2. 3.7 Performance of Instrumentation (1) Instrumentation and management shall be performed by the instrumentation dedicated team. (2) The instrumentation supervisor shall be a civil (geotechnical and foundation) engineer with an understanding of the characteristics of the instrumentation equipment and the behavior of slopes. 3. 2. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) Applying a uniform measurement frequency is inappropriate and should be determined based on the specific slope conditions, site characteristics, and expert review. (2) When determining the measurement frequency, if variations in slope conditions occur and ensuring the safety of workers during construction is a priority, the measurement frequency should be increased. (3) After construction completion or after implementing remedial measures, a normal frequency should be adopted as a general rule. (4) Slope failures or activities often occur due to external factors such as rainfall, snowfall, and earthquakes. In such cases, the measurement frequency should not be limited to the frequency specified in the original measurement plan, and patrols and inspections should be conducted after rainfall and earthquakes, while increasing the measurement frequency to monitor slope behavior. (5) For manual measurements, the slope measurement frequency is in the table. Refer to Table 3.2-1. 3.2-1 Slope Manual Measurement Frequency Targets

*   **Purpose:** To assess the risk level of locations where observations are particularly necessary based on the results of preliminary surveys.
*   **Construction Stage:** Conduct on-site measurements prior to construction to secure safety of construction and countermeasures.
*   **Emergency Response:** To secure the safety of protected objects or human lives and take emergency evacuation measures.
*   **Effect Assessment:** To verify the effectiveness of slope stabilization measures after construction.
*   **Monitoring and Maintenance:** When collapse or slope movement occurs during the construction or maintenance stage. 3. 2. 3.9 Instrumentation Period (1) The instrumentation period shall be established without being excessive or insufficient, considering the purpose of the instrumentation, potential hazards such as slope collapse or landslides, collapse patterns, characteristics of the instrumentation equipment, placement of the instrumentation, site conditions (particularly the structure to be preserved), and other relevant factors. (2) The instrumentation period shall be determined based on the scale and influence of slope deformation, the importance of the structure to be preserved, the presence or absence of countermeasures, and slope facilities. Since slope movements are significantly affected by meteorological factors such as rainfall and snowfall, a period of approximately one year of continuous monitoring is necessary to accurately grasp its dynamics as the optimal duration. (3) Instrumentation shall commence prior to construction if the slope is deemed unstable or hazardous based on preliminary site reconnaissance and rock mass investigation (for purposes such as investigation and explanation of deformation mechanisms, slope stability assessment, comparison with analytical results, and smart construction). (4) Instrumentation shall commence after the completion of countermeasure construction (for purposes such as verification of the effectiveness of countermeasures, establishment of auxiliary countermeasures, and back analysis). (5) Instrumentation shall commence from the time visible deformation is observed on the slope (for purposes such as investigation and explanation of deformation mechanisms, slope stability assessment, construction management, establishment of countermeasures, back analysis, and landslide prediction). (6) The completion of instrumentation is primarily based on the point in time when slope movement is no longer detected through instrumentation. Subsequently, continuous monitoring for one year is required to assess the impacts of snowfall, rainfall, typhoons, and autumn rains on the slope, and completion should be confirmed after verifying that no movement is observed during this period. 3. 2. 3.10 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) All measurement result records shall include the project name, location, slope name, measurement point, measurement items, measurement location, date and time of measurement, and the name of the measurer. (2) Measurement results shall be analyzed by technicians with extensive experience in the design, construction, and measurement of slope excavation projects and a thorough understanding of ground behavior. (3) If the analysis of measurement results indicates a safety issue with the slope, appropriate emergency measures shall be taken, the cause shall be identified, and reinforcement measures shall be devised. 3. 2. 3.11 Instrumentation Management Standards (1) Since instrumentation management standards are determined by the ground behavior, safety limits of adjacent structures, and rock mechanical conditions, it is difficult to present precise numerical values. Therefore, the most rational and practical method is to refer to theoretical and numerical analyses, or construction performance under similar conditions, and to continuously revise the management standards based on initial construction performance. (2) Instrumentation management standards should be set considering the design estimates, slope characteristics, site conditions, and potential damage scale, as they represent a safe level for the instrumentation results. 3. 2. Follow 1.1 and apply to instrumentation for quality control and verticality management of pile foundations and caisson foundations. (2) Instrumentation management for purposes other than those mentioned in (1) shall be performed separately. 3. 3.2 Materials 3. 3. 2.1 Types of Measuring Instruments (1) The diameter of the inspection tube for soundness testing shall be 30mm to 50mm, and the material shall be steel pipe or a material with equivalent strength. (2) The dial gauge shall have an accuracy of 1/100mm or less. 3. 3. 2.2 Other (1) The instruments shall be products suitable for the installation conditions. 3. 3.3 Construction 3. 3. 3.1 Installation of Measuring Instruments (1) Displacement gauges shall be installed on fixed supports in locations unaffected by the settlement and vibration of the piles. (2) The interior of the inspection tubes shall be free from damage such as rust and blockage, and the connections shall be completely waterproofed. (3) Inspection tubes shall be securely fastened within the reinforcing mesh and embedded throughout the entire pile. 3. 3. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for operability before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any abnormalities and calibrate if necessary. 3. 3. 3.3 Protection of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be protected during the measurement period to prevent interference from construction equipment and workers. 3. 3. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Instrument cables shall use instrument-dedicated cables, and during installation, they shall be configured as a single run without any connection points from the buried point to the measurement room. 3. 3. 3.5 Inspection and Testing Following Installation of Measurement System (1) After completing adjustment and testing of the installation work for measurement, a commissioning test shall be performed. 3. 3. During the measurement period, the measuring instruments shall be managed so as not to be affected by construction equipment or workers. 3. 3. 3.7 Instrumentation and Monitoring (1) Pile Driving ① Instrumentation shall be performed to measure the maximum number of blows required for pile driving termination. ② Rebound shall be measured to calculate the bearing capacity using the dynamic bearing capacity formula at the termination of pile driving. (2) Sounding and Verticality ① Measure the blockage status of the sounding tube and the tip depth to verify the sounding depth for each path. If the difference in tip position between tubes is significant, perform separate sounding at the tip. ② Continuously measure while simultaneously pulling up the transmitting sensor and receiving sensor from the tip of the pile, placing them on the same plane perpendicular to the longitudinal direction of the pile. ③ Perform measurements for all possible routes combinable with the number of installed sounding tubes. ④ After completion of the sounding, install protective covers on the tubes to prevent foreign matter from entering until the inspection by the construction supervisor is completed. ⑤ The verticality of precast piles shall be within 1/100, and the position on the plane after installation of the precast piles shall not deviate more than the greater value of D/4 (where D is the diameter of the precast pile) and 100mm from the position specified in the design documents. (3) Caisson Foundation Settlement ① Real-time monitoring of the tilt of the caisson during caisson settlement shall be performed. ② In the event of extreme eccentricity and tilt during settlement, promptly investigate the cause and report it to the construction supervisor, and discuss and implement countermeasures before proceeding with construction. 3. 3. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) Instrumentation for quality control of piles shall be performed at the frequency specified in the design drawings. (2) The measurement frequency for caisson foundation inclination shall be determined to identify the tilt of the caisson not only at the initial settlement point of each segment but also during settlement. 3. 3. You shall submit the necessary documents by consulting with the construction supervisor with reference to 1.4. 3.4 Water and Sewerage Construction 3. 4.1 General Provisions 3. 4. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of ground measurement during the construction of water supply and sanitation works shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. Following 1.1, this aims to ensure safety management and quality control during water and sanitation construction. (2) Measurement management for purposes other than those mentioned in (1) shall be performed separately. 3. 4.2 Ingredients: None 3. 4.3 Construction 3. 4. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) Installation Overview ① The instrumentation supervisor shall install the instrumentation precisely according to the procedures specified in the manufacturer's instructions for the instrumentation. ② Installed instrumentation shall be protected from damage due to construction or other influences. (2) Leakage quantity measuring devices shall be installed before backfilling, for more than 50% of the sewer pipes (stormwater pipes) with a diameter of less than 800mm. (3) Pressure measuring devices shall be installed before backfilling after pipe laying in pressure pipelines. (4) Radiographic testing devices shall be installed after welding of steel pipes. (5) Ultrasonic flaw detection measuring devices shall be installed after welding of steel pipes. (6) Weld pressure measuring devices shall be installed after the completion of internal and external welding of steel pipes. (7) Potential measuring devices shall be installed in locations requiring corrosion prevention measures after laying of water pipes. (8) Flow distribution and head loss measuring devices shall be installed after the completion of the lower collection basin construction. (9) Allowable load capacity measuring devices shall be installed after the completion of equipment assembly. 3. 4. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for anomalies and calibrate if necessary. 3. 4. 3.3 Instrument Management (1) Instruments shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and the reliability of measurement results. (2) In the event that an instrument is damaged due to blasting or other reasons, measurements shall continue after reinstalling an instrument adjacent to the damaged instrument. 3. 4. 3.4 Instrumentation and Measurement (1) Overview ① Instrumentation and management shall be performed by a dedicated instrumentation team. ② The instrumentation supervisor shall be a top-grade technician in the construction field with experience in instrumentation equipment and the water and sewage field, or a specialized technician in non-destructive testing of steel. (2) Leakage Measurement ① Install a rubber stopper (cylinder type) on the lower side of the pipe. ② Inject air into the rubber stopper using a compressor. ③ Install supports to prevent the pipe from moving or the rubber stopper from being pushed back by water pressure. ④ Install a rubber stopper (air release type) on the upper side of the pipe (with the air vent pipe on the top and the water injection pipe on the bottom) and inject air to fix it. ⑤ Connect the water tank and the water injection pipe with a hose. ⑥ Connect the vertical test tube and the air vent pipe with a hose (the position of the vertical test tube is 1m from the water head of the vertical test tube to the upper part inside the pipe). ⑦ Open the valves attached to the water injection pipe and the air vent pipe and slowly fill the pipe with water from the water tank so that no air bubbles are generated. ⑧ When water begins to fill the pipe and water starts to flow out of the air vent pipe, drain a small amount of water and then close the valve attached to the air pipe. ⑨ Continue injecting water into the pipe until the water overflows from the vertical test tube, then close the valve of the water injection pipe. ⑩ Allow the pipe to stand for at least 30 minutes until it is saturated, maintaining the water level at 1m from the upper part inside the pipe (if a large amount of water continuously decreases, stop the work and inspect the pipe for abnormalities). ⑪ Leakage measurement shall be performed by filling the vertical test tube to the top at 5-minute intervals. ⑫ Leakage test results shall be attached to the completion documents. (3) Pressure Test ① Before injecting water for the pressure test, temporarily backfill the pipe to prevent it from moving during the pressure test. ② When injecting water into the pipe, do so slowly while expelling air from the pipe. During the filling process, check if air is being properly vented from air valves, etc., or if there are any abnormalities in the pipe, and take appropriate sealing measures for any leak locations. ③ After the pipe is completely filled, allow it to stand for at least 24 hours to completely expel air from the pipe, especially ensuring that cement mortar and other linings are fully saturated. Then, perform the pressure test and maintain the specified pressure for 24 hours to check for any abnormalities in the pipe and simultaneously measure the leakage rate. ④ For joints with a diameter of 800mm or greater, pressure tests shall be performed on each joint from the inside out using a test band, with the attendance of the construction supervisor as a principle. ⑤ Test band pressure testing is… Maintain at 0.5MPa (N/mm2) or higher for 5 minutes. The water pressure shall not drop below 0.4MPa (N/mm2). If the water pressure drops, it shall be reconnected and a pressure test shall be performed. (4) Ultrasonic inspection① The ultrasonic inspection of field welding joints shall comply with KS B 0817, KS B 0888, KS B 0896, and KS D 0252. (5) Radiographic testing① Prior to commencing the inspection work, obtain approval from the construction supervisor for the inspection method, procedure, and format of the report. (6) Pressure test of welded parts① After the welding of the inner and outer surfaces of the pipe is completed, allow the welded area to cool completely, remove any attached debris, and attach a pressure gauge to the test hole in the welded section.② After attaching the pressure gauge, slowly open the cock of the high-pressure gas compressed gas cylinder to allow the pressure gauge needle to... Ensure it reaches 1.5MPa (N/mm2).③ Pressure After maintaining the pressure at 1.5MPa(N/mm2) for more than 10 minutes, observe for any leaks. If leaks are found, completely remove the weld bead and re-weld, repeating the test. ④ Once the tightness test is complete, remove the attached pressure gauge and weld the test plugs at the weld locations. ⑤ If, due to site conditions, it is unavoidable to maintain the specified tightness test duration, follow the instructions of the site supervisor and proceed with the areas that have passed the tightness test. "Maintain a pressure of 1.5MPa (N/mm2), take record photographs, and then perform corrosion treatment according to the construction supervisor's instructions. (7) Potential Measurement ① Natural potential shall be measured without applying cathodic current to the cathodically protected structure. If current has flowed, it shall be measured after the influence of the current introduced into the structure has completely disappeared. ② Cathodic potential measurement shall be performed after a lapse of 24 hours or more after applying current. ③ The reference value of the cathodic potential shall be based on the saturated copper-copper sulfate electrode –" It shall be 0.85V or less, and the lower limit of the corrosion potential, excluding areas affected by interference such as railways, shall be – with a saturated copper-sulfate reference electrode. 1. General Requirements
1.1 Scope
(1) The voltage shall be maintained at 2.5V or higher. ④ The minimum potential difference between the working current and the natural potential shall be -300mV or lower. ⑤ Electrical protection testing and inspection shall include the following:
a. Insulation resistance measurement according to KS C 1301 and KS C 1302.
b. Withstand voltage test according to KS C 8536.
c. Performance test method for sacrificial anodes for corrosion protection according to KS D 0235.
(8) Flow distribution and head loss measurement
① Sub-collector flow distribution measurement (water)
a. Each sub-collector of the filter shall undergo a visual outflow distribution test to confirm that all orifices are free from blockage by debris and that the flow distribution is uniform.
b. This test shall be performed before the filter media is installed, and the sub-collector shall be filled to approximately half its height with water when the test is initiated.
c. The average backwash flow rate of the test flow shall be higher than the speed specified in the design, and the flow rate shall be measured for approximately 2 minutes to allow for visual observation.
d. The flow distribution test shall be repeated three times, and each time, the flow from each orifice as well as any points where the flow is interrupted or boiling occurs shall be observed.
e. If any problems occur during the test that require correction, appropriate measures shall be taken, and the test shall be repeated after confirmation of the correction.
② Sub-collector flow distribution measurement (air)
a. Each sub-collector of the filter shall undergo a visual outflow distribution test to confirm that all orifices are free from blockage by debris and that the flow distribution is uniform.
b. If any problems occur during the test that require correction, appropriate measures shall be taken, and the test shall be repeated after confirmation of the correction. Furthermore, after the filter media is installed, the sub-collector shall be filled with clean water to a height of approximately 30cm above the top of the sub-collector for testing purposes.
c. The flow rate for the test shall be measured for 2 minutes at the normal backwash speed for air and water.
d. This test shall be repeated three times, and each time, the flow from each orifice as well as any points where the flow is interrupted or boiling occurs shall be observed.
e. If any problems occur during the test that require correction, appropriate measures shall be taken, and the test shall be repeated after confirmation of the correction.
③ Head loss measurement
a. The head loss of the system shall be measured for at least one filter. This measured frictional head loss shall also apply to the lower waterway, crossover pipe, sub-collector, and filter support system.
(9) Allowable Settlement Capacity Measurement
① After the equipment assembly is completed, an operational test of the equipment shall be performed.
② Prior to equipment installation, a detailed plan including equipment transportation, installation method, crane size, and safety measures shall be submitted to the work pit excavation 2 months in advance. 3. 4. 3.5 Measurement Frequency (1) Leakage measurement shall be performed before and after backfilling the pipeline and paving work, with a minimum of one measurement each time. (2) Pressure measurement shall be performed before and after backfilling the pipeline and paving work, with a minimum of one measurement each time. (3) Ultrasonic flaw detection shall be performed at least once after welding the steel pipe and before backfilling. (4) Radiographic testing shall be performed at least once after welding the steel pipe and before backfilling. (5) Weld pressure testing shall be performed at least once after the inner and outer surface welding of the steel pipe and before backfilling. (6) Potential measurement shall be performed at least once for pipelines requiring potential measurement after laying the water pipes. (7) Allowable bearing capacity measurement shall be performed after equipment assembly is complete, and measured at least once. (8) Flow distribution and head loss measurement shall be performed at least once for each filter bed, measuring the test flow rate and head loss after installing the lower collection device and before placing the filter media. 3. 4. 3.6 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) All measurement result records shall include the project name, location, facility name, survey points, measurement items, measurement locations, measurement date and time, and the name of the measurer. (2) Measurement results shall be analyzed by technicians with extensive experience in the water and sewage field or a related construction field. (3) If the measurement analysis results indicate an impact on water and sewage facilities, appropriate emergency measures shall be taken, the cause shall be identified, and permanent countermeasures shall be implemented. (4) Upon completion of the measurement, the measurement results shall be compiled and submitted to the construction supervisor for review and approval before proceeding with subsequent work. 3. 4. 3.7 Instrumentation Management Criteria (1) The instrumentation management criteria may be revised or adjusted based on field conditions and circumstances, with the approval of relevant experts, the managing authority, and the management agency. (2) Leakage measurement is considered acceptable if the water level in the vertical test pipe does not decrease beyond the allowable leakage amount after filling it with water and observing it for 10 minutes. (3) Leakage allowance during pressure testing varies depending on the pipe type, diameter, and joint type. However, for socket joints using rubber rings, the standard is approximately 50L/day to 100L/day for a 10mm diameter and a length of 1km. (4) For radiographic testing, the acceptance criteria for the radiographic examination shall be determined in accordance with KS B 0845, and defects of Class 3 or higher of Type 1 and Type 2 defects shall be considered acceptable. (5) Evaluation of defects using ultrasonic flaw detection shall be based on the thickness of the parent material in a table. A table based on regions defined by the values of A, B, and C in 3.4-1, showing defect indication length and maximum echo height. It is evaluated according to 3.4-2, and acceptance is determined when the defect evaluation point is 3 or less and the sum of the evaluation points per 30cm of the weld with the highest defect density is 5 or less. You shall submit the necessary documents by consulting with the construction supervisor, referring to 1.4. 3.5 Tunnel Construction 3. 5.1 General Provisions 3. 5. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of ground measurement during tunnel construction shall be in accordance with 1. General of this standard. Following 1.1, this measurement management aims to ensure safety during tunnel construction. (2) Measurement management for purposes other than those specified in (1) shall be handled separately. 3. 5.2 Materials 3. 5. 2.1 Types of Measuring Instruments (1) The error of surface and borehole settlement gauges shall be within ±1mm. (2) The measurement error of inner deformation and free-surface settlement gauges shall be within ±1mm. (3) The measurement error of borehole displacement gauges shall be ± It shall be within 0.1mm (4) The accuracy of the lockbolt axial force gauge is... It shall be 0.1kN or more. (5) The shotcrete stress gauge is... It shall have an accuracy of 0.01MPa or greater. (6) The precision of the measuring instrument for measuring the advance displacement ahead of the working face shall be ±. The settlement shall be 0.1mm/m or greater. (7) The center hole jack for rock bolt pull-out testing shall have a capacity of 30kN or more, an accuracy of 5kN or less, and the displacement gauge shall have an accuracy of 1/100mm or less. 3. 5. 2.2 Measurement Data Acquisition System (1) Generally, the automation of measurement management is categorized into three techniques: a semi-automatic measurement management technique that automates the recording of measurement data onto record sheets or storage devices, followed by separate processing using a computer; a fully automatic measurement management technique that consistently performs data collection, analysis, and graphing through a wired or wireless online system; and a technique that combines the two methods. Therefore, a measurement data acquisition system should be selected. 3. 5.3 Construction 3. 5. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) Surface and Ground Settlement Meters Surface and ground settlement meters shall be installed at a time when initial readings can be taken before the tunnel boring machine reaches a location three times the tunnel diameter from the installation location. However, if it is anticipated that the influence of tunnel advancement will extend beyond three times the tunnel diameter due to special ground conditions, the instruments shall be installed and initial readings taken before the occurrence of any displacement. (2) Inner Convergence and Crown Settlement Meters Inner convergence and crown settlement measurement points shall be installed immediately after sealing shotcrete is applied and before excavation of the next heading begins, to allow for initial readings to be taken and to maximize the measurement of displacement due to tunnel advancement. (3) Ground Convergence Gauges ① Measurement points for ground convergence gauges shall be securely fixed to the ground to adequately reflect ground deformation. ② Ground convergence gauges shall be installed immediately after the first shotcrete layer is applied and initial readings taken before the next heading is advanced to maximize the measurement of displacement due to tunnel advancement. (4) Rock Bolt Axial Force Gauges ① Rock bolt axial force gauges shall be installed immediately after the first shotcrete layer is applied and at a time when they are sufficiently bonded to the ground before excavation of the next heading begins, to maximize the measurement of axial force changes due to tunnel advancement. ② Rock bolt axial force gauges shall be securely fixed to the ground to adequately reflect the axial force changes at the measurement point installation location due to ground deformation. ③ The materials, specifications, and backfill of the rock bolts used for axial force measurement shall be the same as those of the rock bolts actually used in construction. (5) Shotcrete Stress Gauges ① Shotcrete stress gauges shall be installed during shotcrete application and initial readings taken before the next heading advancement to maximize the measurement of axial force changes due to tunnel advancement. (6) Advance Convergence Gauges Ahead of Breakthrough ① Advance convergence measurements shall be taken by installing the instruments in front of the tunnel face before the breakthrough face advances to anticipate the degree of ground settlement ahead of the breakthrough. ② They shall be installed on the same line as the crown settlement measurements within the tunnel to allow for mutual comparison of vertical settlement measurement results. ③ The drilling angle of the instruments should be drilled upward at approximately 7-10° to consider the dip angle during drilling and interference from auxiliary methods, and they should be protected from damage by tunnel work, such as rock bolts or auxiliary methods. ④ Since the calculation of displacement through advance convergence measurement shall be performed as a cumulative displacement using the innermost hole (instrument #1) of the drilled hole as the reference point, the individual installation length of the instruments must be sufficiently long to prevent errors caused by displacement. 3. 5. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change unusually during measurement, the measuring instrument shall be checked for abnormalities and calibrated if necessary. (3) As a general rule, measuring instruments shall be periodically calibrated by a national accredited calibration agency or an agency with equivalent qualifications, but in cases where there is no such calibration agency in Korea or for equipment using new technologies, the manufacturer's manual shall be followed. 3. 5. 3.3 Protection of Instruments (1) Installed instruments shall be protected from damage due to construction or other influences. 3. 5. 3.4 Instrumentation Management (1) Instrumentation shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures specified by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and the reliability of measurement results. (2) The area around installed instrumentation within the tunnel shall maintain adequate illumination for instrumentation management and measurement, and a sign indicating the instrument name, location, initial measurement date, and initial measurement value shall be installed and managed. (3) In the event that instrumentation is damaged due to blasting or other reasons, measurement shall continue after reinstalling instrumentation adjacent to the damaged instrument. 3. 5. 3.5 Performance of Instrumentation (1) The execution and management of instrumentation shall be carried out either by the contractor directly operating an in-house instrumentation team or by entrusting it to a specialized instrumentation company. (2) The Instrumentation Manager shall be a technician with a major in geotechnical engineering or geology who understands the characteristics of instrumentation and the behavior of ground and support structures resulting from tunnel excavation. 3. 5. 3.6 Measurement Frequency (1) Inner Convergence, Head Drop, Ground Displacement, and Rock Bolt ① The measurement frequency of Inner Convergence and Head Drop is shown in the table. Determine based on displacement velocity or heading distance as in 3.5-1, but adjust according to the displacement pattern. Table. 3.5-1 Inner Convergence and Crown Settlement Measurement Frequency		Measurement Frequency			Displacement Rate			Advance Distance			Remarks			2 times/day			More than 10mm/day			0D～1D			D refers to tunnel diameter			1 time/day			10～5mm/day			1D ~ 2D			1 time/2 days			5～1mm/day			2D ~ 5D			1 time/week			1mm/day or less			5D or more (2) Surface and Ground Settlement Frequency ① The measurement frequency of surface and ground settlement gauges shall be determined by considering the advance distance, advance rate, behavior of ground and support structure, and shall be appropriately adjusted according to the measurement results as a standard. a.
