Here, D refers to the tunnel diameter. (3) The measurement items and frequency may be adjusted after obtaining confirmation from the site supervisor, taking into account site conditions and ground conditions. 3. 5. 3.7 Measurement Period (1) The measurement period for instrumentation during tunnel construction shall be from the installation of the instrumentation equipment until convergence of the measured values is confirmed. 3. 5. 3.8 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) All measurement result records shall include the project name, location, tunnel name, measurement point, measurement items, measurement location, measurement date and time, and measurement personnel. (2) Measurement results shall be organized separately for each measurement item in a predetermined format, including measurement date, elapsed days, chainage (distinguished as advance and retreat), initial value, current displacement, and accumulated displacement.  'Time (elapsed days)-Measurement value' and 'Chainage-Measurement value' graphs shall be plotted to quickly identify trends in measurement values, and these results shall be used for subsequent work. (3) Measurement results shall be analyzed under the responsibility of the measurement supervisor by a technician specializing in geotechnical engineering with extensive experience in tunnel construction, to understand ground behavior. (4) The measurement supervisor shall analyze, referring to numerical analysis results, experience, other measurement results, and site ground conditions performed in the same or similar sites, and shall establish measurement control criteria based on the absolute change and change rate of measurement values, and evaluate stability accordingly. Furthermore, when applying management criteria based on design-predicted displacement for stability evaluation and implementation of countermeasures (such as changes to the support pattern), evaluation should not be based solely on the results of individual items, but rather should comprehensively consider related measurement items (support member stress, thrust force, etc.) to develop reasonable countermeasures.  At this time, the measurement control criteria shall be obtained through approval from the site supervisor. (5) If the analysis of measurement results indicates that the tunnel's safety is affected, the site supervisor shall instruct the contractor to take appropriate emergency measures and investigate the cause to develop permanent countermeasures. (6) Upon completion of measurements, the measurement results shall be compiled and submitted to the site supervisor for review and approval before proceeding with subsequent work. 3. 5. 3.9 Instrumentation Management Criteria (1) As instrumentation management criteria are determined by the ground behavior, safety limits of adjacent structures, and rock mechanical conditions, it is difficult to present precise numerical values. Therefore, the most rational and practical approach is to refer to theoretical and numerical analyses, or construction performance under similar conditions, and to continuously revise the management criteria based on initial construction performance. (2) The primary management criteria serve as target-setting benchmarks for construction management, the secondary management criteria are designed to prepare for potential impacts on surrounding structures, and the tertiary management criteria aim to mitigate risks specific to the tunnel itself. 3. 5. "3.10 Measurement Result Report (1) The measurement result report is of this standard," 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. 5. "3.11 Submission (1) The submission is of this standard." You shall submit the necessary documents through consultation with the construction supervisor, referring to 1.4. 3.6 Dam Construction 3. 6.1 General Provisions 3. 6. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of ground instrumentation during dam construction shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. Following 1.1, this aims to ensure safety management and quality control during dam construction. (2) Measurement management for purposes other than those mentioned in (1) shall be handled separately. 3. 6.2 Materials 3. 6. 2.1 Types of Instruments (1) The measurement error limit of instruments measuring external deformation occurring on the dam body surface is ± "1.0mm or less. (2) The measurement error limit of the instrument measuring the settlement occurring inside the dam body shall be ±" It shall be within 1.0mm. (3) The measurement range of strain rate due to concrete temperature change shall be 3,000με or more, and the minimum measurement value is. 0.1με 이하이어야 한다.(4) 표면차수벽의 비탈면에 설치하는 경사 계측기기는 ±90° 이상, 댐 중앙에 설치하는 수직경사 계측기기는 ±50° 이상을 측정할 수 있어야 한다.(5) 콘크리트 표면차수벽형 석괴댐의 경우 차수벽과 프린스 이음부의 3방향별 변위를 측정하여야 하는 변위계의 측정범위는 최소 100mm 이상이어야 하며, 측정오차의 한계는 ± The displacement shall not exceed 0.01mm.(6) The instrumentation for measuring the stress of the concrete waterproofing wall shall be installed in sets of three, using a rosette block to install in the 0°, 45°, and 90° directions as a principle.(7) The measurement range of pore water pressure shall be planned considering the design working pore water pressure, and shall be able to measure at least 1MPa. 3. 6. 2.2 Data Acquisition System for Instrumentation (1) Dam instrumentation should be linked with both construction-phase and maintenance-phase monitoring to detect early warning signs, which is crucial for preventing or minimizing damage. It requires real-time monitoring and prompt transmission and processing of information, and it is a principle to use an automated instrumentation system that consistently handles data collection, processing, and interpretation. (2) The automated data acquisition system shall transmit instrumentation data from the instruments to the computer in the remote monitoring room, allowing for data storage and analysis on the remote computer, and shall be planned as a system that allows for manual instrumentation when necessary. (3) The automated data acquisition system shall be planned to allow remote control of instrumentation equipment at each point from a remote location to adjust the frequency of measurements. (4) When using the automated data acquisition system, a power supply unit shall be installed to stably acquire, store, and transmit instrumentation data, and auxiliary equipment such as voltage stabilization devices, dehumidifiers, thermostats, and lightning protection devices shall be installed. If necessary, vibration isolation devices shall be planned to prevent the influence of vibration. 3. 6.3 construction 3. 6. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) For homogeneous dams, instrument cables should be minimized in length and installed in the downstream monitoring room. For arch dams, cables should run through the same zone and be installed on either the right or left bank as a principle. (2) Lead wires connecting instrumentation and circuit relay lines shall be reinforced with steel wire, etc., for installation in rock layers, soil layers, or concrete, whether buried or exposed, to ensure accurate transmission of instrument data. Reinforcement, waterproofing, corrosion prevention, and insulation treatments shall be provided against tension, external forces, impact, lightning strikes, etc. (3) Instruments and lead wires embedded in the dam body or structures shall be inspected immediately after installation, and concrete placement or backfilling work shall only be performed if normal operation is observed. (4) Inclination measuring instruments installed in the dam body's deep wall shall be installed and connected separately for each construction stage, and the center of the top of the existing construction stage tube shall have a level and verticality of ±". 1.0mm accuracy shall be ensured. (5) Instrumentation for stress and strain measurement of the dam body shall be installed in accordance with the following methods. ① To install the pore pressure measuring instrument, a trench with a minimum length of 1m shall be excavated. ② The lower part of the excavation shall be compacted to a minimum depth of 30cm using a manual tamper or rammer, and the upper part shall be divided into layers to ensure perfect compaction and backfilling. ③ The excavation slope shall be gentler than 1:1, and the surface to be measured for pore pressure shall be leveled to remove any protrusions before installing the instrument. ④ The measuring surface of the pore pressure measuring instrument shall be installed vertically in the direction of the pore pressure acting, and fixed to prevent movement. ⑤ The pore pressure tip shall be immersed in deionized water for 24 hours prior to installation and protected from direct sunlight. After storage, connect the indicator to the cable and install it when the reading is consistent, indicating no air pockets. (6) Instrumentation for stress and strain measurement of concrete shall be installed in accordance with the following methods. ① Vertical joint displacement gauges shall be embedded in the vertical joints in two stages: during the first concrete placement and during the subsequent concrete placement. ② Since the instrument is buried in concrete, it shall be welded and sealed and have anti-corrosion treatment. ③ Instruments for measuring concrete stress shall not be in direct contact with the bottom of the concrete and shall be protected from damage to the contact surface due to concrete placement. ④ Zero-stress strain gauges shall be installed at the same location as the stress measuring instruments. ⑤ Zero-stress strain gauges shall be placed in specially manufactured containers for embedding, and installed under the same temperature and humidity conditions as the surrounding concrete. ⑥ Zero-stress strain gauges shall be prevented from floating away from the contact surface due to concrete placement, and concrete shall be placed gradually within the container. 3. 6. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any abnormalities and calibrate if necessary. 3. 6. 3.3 Protection of Instruments (1) Instruments with exposed parts after installation shall be protected by appropriate protective measures to prevent damage from construction equipment or personnel, and warning signs shall be posted in a conspicuous location. 3. 6. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Cables for transmitting measurement data shall be selected in a format suitable for continuous measurement, and installation plans shall be established including cable routing, communication standards, and cable connection and termination. (2) Measurement instrument cables shall use dedicated measurement instrument cables, and shall be configured as a single run from the buried point to the measurement room without any connection points during installation. (3) Cables shall be routed with sufficient slack to prevent tensile stress on the cables due to settlement of the measurement instruments. (4) Wiring for all measurement instruments shall be protected by installing measurement-specific conduits. (5) The cross-sectional area of measurement conduits shall not exceed 32% of the cable cross-sectional area. (6) Measurement conduits shall be used exclusively for measurement cables. However, other cables that do not interfere with the communication of measurement cables may be used jointly upon confirmation by the construction supervisor. (7) The ends of the cables shall be waterproofed to prevent water penetration during measurement and maintenance. (8) The ends of the cables shall be marked with the type, number, and type of wire of the measurement instrument to prevent them from being swapped. (9) All data transmission equipment shall consider compatibility when selecting transmission equipment in preparation for the operation of the measurement system, taking into account future expandability and scalability. 3. 6. 3.5 Inspection and Testing of Measurement System Installation (1) The inspection conducted upon delivery at the site shall be performed with the attachment of test reports from an accredited agency for all equipment. However, the test reports from the manufacturer themselves may be substituted if approved by the client. ① In the case of products marked with the Korean Industrial Standards (KS) designation under the Industrial Standardization Act ② In the case of products that have obtained a quality grade under the Electrical Appliance and Consumer Goods Safety Act ③ In the case of products that have passed the type approval for telecommunications equipment under the Telecommunications Business Act (2) After completing adjustment and testing for long-term or continuous measurement, the following commissioning tests shall be performed. ① The technical supervisor responsible for the installation of measuring instruments shall be responsible for the primary commissioning of the equipment under no-load conditions and shall prepare and submit a test report to the construction supervisor upon completion of the test. ② Comprehensive commissioning shall be a commissioning test under load, including comprehensive commissioning of other equipment related to the main equipment, to ensure that the overall function can be achieved. ③ The commissioning test period shall be a minimum of 30 days. 3. 6. 3.6 Instrumentation Management (1) Instrumentation shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and reliability of measurement results. (2) Regular reliability assessments of instrumentation shall be conducted, and the reliability assessment should comprehensively consider the judgment based on time-dependent changes, the judgment based on electrical inspection, and the judgment based on analysis of measurement results, including dam body behavior analysis. 3. 6. 3.7 Performance of Instrumentation (1) The execution and management of instrumentation shall be performed by the dedicated instrumentation team. (2) The instrumentation manager shall be a top-grade technician in the relevant construction field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation and the behavior of the dam and ground. 3. 6. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) The measurement period during construction is divided into four stages as follows, and the measurement frequency for each stage is shown in the table. Shall be the same as 3.6-1. Considering the measurement results, on-site conditions, and ground conditions, the measurement frequency may be adjusted after securing the validity of the change through measurement data analysis, etc., and upon confirmation by the site supervisor. ① Stage 1: For 1 month after installation of measurement equipment ② Stage 2: From 1 month after installation of measurement equipment until completion of the dam ③ Stage 3: Until safety is confirmed in cases where the measured values show abnormal behavior ④ Stage 4: For 1 week after flood control or earthquake occurrence. 3.6-1 Dam Construction Instrumentation Frequency | Instrumentation Items | Stage 1 | Stage 2 | Stage 3 | Stage 4 | Pore Water Pressure | Groundwater Level | Internal Settlement and Layer-wise Settlement | Daily | Weekly | Daily | Daily | Joint Displacement | Vertical Joint Horizontal Displacement | Dam Body and Concrete Strain | Concrete Unstressed Strain | Slope Displacement | Daily | Weekly | Daily | Daily | External Displacement and Foundation Settlement | Daily | Daily | Daily | Daily | Automatic Instrumentation Records and Computer Control Equipment | Daily | Daily | Daily | Daily (2) Since the results of each instrumentation item require cross-comparison analysis, related instrumentation items shall be measured at the same time, and those with higher frequency shall be measured separately. (3) When phenomena affecting dam stability, such as abnormal flood or earthquakes, occur, immediate measurement and analysis shall be performed to determine whether the dam body and structures are abnormal, and if abnormalities are found, permanent measures shall be taken. 3. 6. 3.9 Measurement Period (1) The measurement period for instrumentation during dam construction shall continue from the installation of the instrumentation equipment until the completion of the construction, and shall be transitioned to maintenance monitoring. 3. 6. 3.10 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) All measurement result records shall include the project name, location, dam name, measurement point, measurement item, measurement location, date and time of measurement, and the name of the measurer. (2) Measurement results shall be separately organized by measurement item in a predetermined format, including measurement date, number of days elapsed, construction status, initial value, current measurement value, and change in value. Graphs for analyzing measurement data shall be presented as time-series changes by location and distribution diagrams of measurement items in the dam body for each measurement item, so that the results can be utilized for construction management and safety management. (3) Measurement results shall be analyzed by technicians in the construction-related field who are capable of analyzing dam and ground behavior. (4) If the results of the measurement analysis are deemed to affect the safety of the dam, appropriate emergency measures shall be taken, the cause shall be identified, and permanent countermeasures shall be devised. (5) Analysis of Stress and Deformation Measurement Results of the Dam Body ① Review the dam body stress distribution and principal stresses through the soil pressure measurement results to verify the adequacy of the design and the stability of the dam body, and examine the possibility of hydraulic fracture due to stress transfer. ② The stability of the dam body shall be assessed based on time-varying deformation, deformation rate, and the occurrence of differential settlement, and the settlement amount and horizontal displacement shall be measured simultaneously to analyze the mutual influence and the displacement amount for each total construction height, and applied to the dam body stability assessment. ③ The tilt measurement results installed on the concrete cutoff wall shall be analyzed together with the dam body deformation results to examine the possibility of deformation and cracking of the concrete cutoff wall. (6) Analysis of Stress and Deformation Measurement Results of Concrete ① Analyze the displacement of components such as joints around the concrete surface cutoff wall where tensile stress is applied to examine the stability from the perspectives of short-term stability during construction and long-term durability. ② Utilize the zero-stress strain measurement results to identify external stresses acting on the concrete and internal stresses spontaneously generated by temperature changes, etc., and apply them to construction quality control and dam body stability evaluation. (7) Analysis of Pore Water Pressure Measurement Results of the Dam Body and Surrounding Ground ① Analyze the effective stress and shear strength by location through the pore water pressure generated within the wall to apply to the stability assessment of the dam body during construction. ② In the case of a concrete dam, utilize the hydrostatic pressure acting on the dam body to apply to the stability assessment of the dam body. 3. 6. 3.11 Instrumentation Management Standards (1) Instrumentation management standards vary depending on the type and scale of the dam, the behavior of the dam abutments and foundation ground, geological conditions, construction materials, and construction methods. Therefore, it is difficult to present clear standard values, and these factors should be considered when determining the standards for each instrumentation item. Generally, it is reasonable to determine the standards based on a comprehensive review of laboratory tests, theoretical and numerical analyses, and instrumentation results from initial construction performance and dams with similar conditions. (2) Pore water pressure distribution diagrams and earth pressure measurement results in the dam body should be used to regulate the construction speed during dam construction by adjusting the construction speed and height, and the moisture content of the construction materials. (3) Instrumentation management standards for each instrumentation item may be set in the form of absolute values or trends and may be amended or adjusted based on site conditions and circumstances with the approval of site-specific experts, the management authority, and the supervising agency. 3. 6. "3.12 Measurement Result Report (1) The measurement result report is of this standard," 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. 6. "3.13 Submission (1) The submission is based on this standard." Referring to 1.4, the necessary documents shall be submitted after consultation with the construction supervisor. 3.7 River Embankment Construction 3. General Provisions 3. 7. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of application of ground measurement during the construction of river embankment works shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. "Following 1.1, this aims to ensure safety management and quality control during river embankment construction. (2) Instrumentation management for purposes other than those mentioned in (1) shall be performed separately." 3. 7.2 Materials 3. 7. 2.1 Types of Instrumentation (1) The measurement error limit of instruments measuring levee deformation is ± It shall be within 1.0mm. (2) The measurement error limit of the measuring instrument for measuring embankment settlement shall be ±. It shall be within 1.0mm. (3) The displacement gauge used to measure the horizontal displacement of the levee shall have a measurement range of at least 100mm, and the limit of measurement error shall be ±. It shall be within 0.01mm. (4) The measurement range of the hydraulic pressure in the gap shall be planned considering the design operating hydraulic pressure in the gap, and it should be able to measure at least 1MPa as a basic requirement. 3. 7. 2.2 Data Acquisition System for Instrumentation (1) For river levee instrumentation, it is a principle to use an automated instrumentation system that consistently processes the collection, processing, and interpretation of instrumentation data when establishing an instrumentation plan that integrates instrumentation during construction as well as maintenance and management instrumentation. (2) The automated data acquisition device shall transmit instrumentation data from the instruments to the computer in the remote monitoring room, allowing for storage and analysis of the instrumentation data on the remote computer, and shall be planned as a system that allows for manual instrumentation when necessary. (3) When using an automated data acquisition device, power supply equipment and auxiliary equipment such as voltage stabilization devices, dehumidifiers, temperature control devices, and lightning protection devices shall be installed to ensure stable acquisition, storage, and transmission of instrumentation data, and vibration isolation devices shall be planned as necessary to prevent the influence of vibration. 3. 7.3 Construction 3. 7. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) The instrumentation to be used on-site shall be selected and purchased based on the site conditions and intended purpose. Before purchasing and installing the instrumentation, the specifications of all equipment must be submitted to and approved by the client. (2) To prevent the cables from being severed or damaged even if the levee subsides, the cables shall be installed with sufficient slack to reach the levee surface using an appropriate method. The ends of the cables shall be marked with the type, number, and wire type of the instrumentation to prevent confusion. (3) The instrumentation supervisor shall install the equipment accurately in accordance with the procedures specified in the manufacturer's instructions for the instrumentation. 3. 7. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any abnormalities and calibrate if necessary. 3. 7. 3.3 Protection of Instrumentation (1) For lead wires connecting the instrumentation to the circuit relay line, in the case of levee foundation ground and levee burial, they shall be reinforced with steel wire or the like, and shall be reinforced, waterproofed, and treated against corrosion and insulation against tension, external force, impact, lightning, etc. (2) The instrumentation responsible person shall review the installation instructions for each device in advance to identify potential issues that may arise during installation and establish instrumentation protection measures accordingly. 3. 7. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Instrument cables shall use dedicated instrument cables, and shall be configured as a single run without any connection points from the buried point to the measurement room during installation. (2) The cable ends shall be waterproofed to prevent water penetration from the time of measurement to maintenance. 3. 7. 3.5 Inspection and Testing Following Instrumentation System Installation (1) Instruments and lead wires embedded in dikes or structures shall be inspected immediately after installation, and backfilling work shall only proceed if normal operation is confirmed. 3. 7. 3.6 Management of Instrumentation (1) Instrumentation shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and reliability of measurement results. (2) Regular reliability assessments of the instrumentation shall be conducted, and the reliability assessment shall comprehensively consider the determination based on time-dependent changes, the determination based on electrical inspection, and the determination based on analysis of measurement results such as dam behavior analysis. 3. 7. 3.7 Instrumentation Implementation (1) Instrumentation and management shall be performed by the instrumentation dedicated team. (2) The instrumentation manager shall be a technician in the construction-related field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation and the behavior of the levee and ground. (3) The instrumentation equipment shall be measured at least three times on the same day, and the average value shall be adopted as the measurement result. 3. Seven. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) The measurement period during construction is divided into 4 stages as follows, and the measurement frequency for each stage is shown in the table. "Shall be the same as 3.7-1. When changing the frequency of measurements, taking into account measurement results, on-site conditions, and ground conditions, the validity of the change shall be secured through measurement data analysis, etc., and adjusted after obtaining the confirmation of the site supervisor. ① Stage 1: For one month after installation of measuring instruments ② Stage 2: From one month after installation of measuring instruments until completion of the levee ③ Stage 3: When measurements show abnormal behavior and safety is confirmed ④ Stage 4: For one week after occurrence of flood or earthquake." 3.7-1 River Levee Construction Monitoring Frequency and Contents

(2) Since the results of each monitoring item require cross-analysis, related monitoring items should be measured at the same time, and those with higher frequency should be measured separately. 3. Seven. 3.9 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) All measurement result records shall include the project name, location, levee name, measurement point, measurement item, measurement location, date and time of measurement, and measurement personnel. (2) Measurement results, including measurement date, elapsed days, construction status, initial value, current measurement value, and change in value, shall be separately organized according to measurement item in a predetermined format. Graphs for analyzing measurement data shall show time-series changes by location and distribution diagrams of measurement items by levee for each measurement item, so that the results can be utilized for construction management and safety management. (3) Measurement results shall be analyzed by technicians in the construction-related field with extensive experience in levee construction and an understanding of levee and ground behavior. (4) Measurement results shall be analyzed with reference to design documents, numerical analysis results performed in the subject site or similar sites, empirical data, other measurement results, and on-site conditions. Absolute change in measurement values and change rate shall be referenced to set measurement management criteria and assess stability accordingly. (5) In the event of abnormal flood, earthquake, or other phenomena affecting levee stability, immediate measurement and analysis shall be performed to determine the presence of abnormalities in the levee and structure, and permanent countermeasures shall be taken if abnormalities are found. (6) Upon completion of measurement, the measurement results shall be compiled and submitted to the construction supervisor for review and approval before proceeding with subsequent work. 3. 7. 3.10 Instrumentation Management Criteria (1) Instrumentation management criteria vary depending on factors such as embankment scale, the condition of the embankment slopes and foundation ground, geological conditions, construction materials, and construction methods. Therefore, it is difficult to present clear standard values, and these factors should be considered when determining the criteria for each instrumentation item. Generally, it is reasonable to determine the criteria based on a comprehensive review of indoor tests, theoretical and numerical analysis, and instrumentation results from initial construction performance and embankments with similar conditions. (2) Measurement results of pore water pressure distribution in the embankment should be used to regulate the construction speed during embankment construction by adjusting the construction speed, fill height, and water content of the construction materials. (3) Instrumentation management criteria for each instrumentation item can be set in the form of absolute values or trend lines and may be amended or adjusted by on-site experts, the management authority, or the supervising agency, depending on the site conditions and circumstances. 3. Seven. "3.11 Measurement Result Report (1) The measurement result report is in accordance with this standard." 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. Seven. 3.12 Submission (1) The submission is of this standard. Referring to 1.4, necessary documents shall be submitted after consultation with the superintendent. 3.8 Port Authority 3. General Provisions 3. Eight. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of application of ground measurement during port construction projects shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. Following 1.1, this aims to ensure safety management and quality control during port construction. (2) Measurement management for purposes other than those specified in (1) shall be performed separately. 3. 8.2 Materials 3. 8. 2.1 Types of Instruments (1) The measurement error limit of instruments measuring deformation is ± It shall be within 1.0mm. (2) The measurement error limit of the instrument used to measure settlement shall be ±. It shall be within 1.0mm. (3) The measurement range of concrete strain shall be 3,000με or greater, and the minimum measurement value is... It should be 0.1με or less. 3. Eight. 2.2 Data Acquisition System (1) The automated data acquisition system shall transmit measurement data from the instruments to the computer in the remote monitoring room, enabling storage and analysis of the measurement data on the remote computer. It shall be planned as a system that allows for manual measurement when necessary. (2) The automated data acquisition system shall be planned to allow remote control of instruments at each point from a remote location to adjust the measurement frequency. 3. 8.3 Construction 3. Eight. 3.1 Installation of Instrumentation (1) Instrumentation shall be installed on the port structures and adjacent ground at the installation points, and installed to accurately measure the behavior of those points. (2) Instrumentation required for the measurement of port structures shall, as a principle, be installed during the fabrication of the port structures. (3) Instrumentation of the ground around port structures shall, as a principle, be installed before the construction of the port structures. (4) The instrumentation supervisor shall install the instruments accurately in accordance with the procedures specified in the manufacturer's instructions provided with the instrumentation. 3. Eight. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated as necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any abnormalities and calibrate as necessary. 3. Eight. 3.3 Protection of Instrumentation (1) Cables between instrumentation and data acquisition systems shall be capable of accurately transmitting data from each instrument, even when buried within rock, soil, or concrete, or exposed. They shall be reinforced against tensile forces, external forces, impact, lightning strikes, etc., and shall undergo waterproofing, anti-corrosion, and insulation treatments. 3. Eight. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Instrumentation cables shall use dedicated instrumentation cables, and shall be constructed as a single run without any connection points from the buried point to the measurement room during installation. (2) In preparation for ground subsidence, protective measures shall be provided for the cables to prevent breakage or damage, and the ends of the cables shall be marked with the type, number, and type of wire of the instrumentation to prevent them from being mixed up. (3) The ends of the cables shall be waterproofed to prevent water from penetrating from the time of measurement to maintenance. 3. Eight. 3.5 Inspection and Testing Following Instrumentation System Installation (1) Instrumentation installed within or on port structures and in the surrounding ground shall be immediately measured after installation, and subsequent work shall only proceed if normal operation is confirmed. 3. Eight. 3.6 Instrumentation Management (1) Instrumentation shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and reliability of measurement results. (2) Periodic reliability assessments of instrumentation shall be conducted, and the reliability assessment should comprehensively consider judgments based on time-dependent changes, judgments based on electrical inspections, and analysis of measurement results such as port structure behavior analysis. 3. 8. 3.7 Performance of Instrumentation (1) The execution and management of instrumentation shall be performed by the designated instrumentation team. (2) The instrumentation supervisor shall be a technician in the construction-related field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation equipment and the behavior of the port structures and surrounding ground. (3) The instrumentation equipment shall be measured at least three times on the same day each time, and the average value shall be adopted as the measurement result. 3. Eight. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) The measurement period during construction is divided into 5 stages as follows, and the measurement frequency for each stage is shown in the table. 3.8-1, 3.8-2 is equivalent. ① Port structure a. 1st stage: Port structure fabrication stage b. 2nd stage: Port structure placement stage c. 3rd stage: Port structure backfilling stage d. 4th stage: Routine measurement stage (Routine measurement stage after the 3rd stage is completed without any abnormal signs) e. 5th stage: Emergency measurement stage (In case of abnormal signs on the port structure) Table 3.8-1 Measurement Frequency for Port Structure Sections		Measurement Items			Port Structure Construction Stage			Port Structure	Placement Stage			Port Structure Backfilling Stage			Routine Monitoring Stage			Emergency Monitoring Stage			Port Structure Settlement			Port Structure Horizontal Displacement and Tilt			-			1 time/10 min			1 time/30 min 			1 time/day			1 time/10 min			Reinforcement Stress Gauge	Concrete Stress	Earth Pressure Gauge	Reaction Gauge			1 time/hour			1 time/10 min			1 time/30 min 			1 time/day			1 time/10 min	② Surrounding Ground a. Stage 1: Rock Mound Placement Stage b. Stage 2: Port Structure Placement Stage c. Stage 3: Port Structure Backfilling Stage d. Stage 4: Routine Monitoring Stage (After Stage 3 completion and without abnormal signs, routine monitoring stage) e. Stage 5: Emergency Monitoring Stage (In case of abnormal signs in the surrounding ground) Table 3.8-2 Ground Instrumentation Frequency Around the Structure		Instrumentation Items			Rock Mound Placement Stage			Structure Placement Stage			Structure Backfilling Stage			Routine Monitoring Stage			Emergency Monitoring Stage			Land-Based Surface Settlement			Land-Based Layer Settlement			Land-Based Ground Displacement			1/30 min			1/10 min			1/30 min			1/1 day			1/10 min			Structure Lower Portion Settlement			Structure Lower Portion Layer Settlement			Rock Mound Settlement			1/30 min			1/10 min			1/30 min			1/1 day			1/10 min			Seaward Ground Displacement			1/30 min			1/10 min			1/30 min			1/1 day			1/10 min			Tide Gauge			1/30 min			1/10 min			1/30 min			1/1 hour			1/10 min	(2) Instrumentation frequency shall be set differently for the caisson section and the surrounding ground section. (3) If the instrumentation frequency needs to be changed considering the instrumentation results, site conditions, and ground conditions, the validity of the change shall be secured through instrumentation data analysis, etc., and adjusted after obtaining confirmation from the construction supervisor. (4) Since the results of each instrumentation item require cross-analysis, related instrumentation items shall be measured at the same time, and the item with the higher frequency shall be measured separately. 3. 8. 3.9 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) Measurement results shall be analyzed by technicians in the construction-related field with extensive experience in port construction and an understanding of port structures and ground behavior. (2) All measurement result records shall include the project name, location, structure name, measurement point, measurement item, measurement location, date and time of measurement, and the name of the measurer. (3) Measurement results, including measurement date, elapsed days, construction status, initial values, current measurement values, and changes, shall be separately organized according to measurement items in a predetermined format. Graphs for analyzing measurement data shall be presented as time-series changes by location and distribution diagrams by measurement item for each measurement item, so that the results can be utilized for construction management and safety management. (4) If the measurement analysis results indicate that the port structure’s safety is affected, appropriate emergency measures shall be taken, the cause shall be identified, and permanent countermeasures shall be devised. (5) Upon completion of measurement, the measurement results shall be compiled and submitted to the construction supervisor for review before proceeding with subsequent work. (6) Analysis of Measurement Results for Port Structures ① The measurement results of stress and reaction force (lateral pressure) of the port structure shall be used to examine the stress distribution of the caisson, verify the appropriateness of the design, and confirm the stability of the structure, as well as to determine the reaction force status during placement and during the installation of the overburden blocks. ② The deformation of the port structure shall be assessed for basic stabilization through time-series changes, deformation rate, and the presence of differential settlement. Settlement amount and horizontal displacement (tilt) shall be measured simultaneously to verify the behavior of the port structure during construction. (7) Analysis of Measurement Results for the Ground around Port Structures ① Measurement results of ground settlement and horizontal displacement installed in the surrounding ground shall be analyzed together with the deformation and stress results of the port structure to examine the possibility of abnormal ground behavior due to backfilling and embankment. 3. 8. 3.10 Instrumentation Management Criteria (1) Instrumentation results are analyzed with reference to design documents, numerical analysis results performed in the site or similar sites, empirical data, results from other instrumentation, and site conditions. Instrumentation management criteria are established based on the absolute change in instrumentation values and their rate of change, and stability is assessed accordingly. (2) Instrumentation management criteria vary depending on the type and scale of the port structure, surrounding ground, geological conditions, tidal levels, and construction methods, making it difficult to present clear standard values. Therefore, these factors should be considered for each instrumentation item when determining the criteria. Generally, it is reasonable to determine the criteria through a comprehensive review based on indoor testing, theory and numerical analysis, and instrumentation results from initial construction performance and port structures with similar conditions. (3) Measurement results of subsidence and horizontal displacement of the port structure and surrounding ground should be utilized to regulate port construction, adjusting construction speed, backfilling speed, and placement speed. (4) Instrumentation management criteria for each instrumentation item can be set as absolute values, trend lines, or displacement rates and may be modified or adjusted by site-specific experts, the management authority, and the supervisory agency, depending on site conditions and circumstances. 3. Eight. "3.10 Measurement Result Report (1) The measurement result report is of this standard," 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. 8. "3.11 Submission(1) The submission is of this standard," You shall submit the necessary documents through consultation with the construction supervisor, referring to 1.4. 3.9 Construction Works 3. General Provisions 3. 9. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of ground measurement during construction of building works shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. Following 1.1, this aims to ensure safety management during the construction of building structures. (2) This includes the installation and monitoring of instruments during the construction process for post-completion building measurements (1). (3) Measurements during building construction are performed to ensure the ultimate safety of the structure by measuring parameters such as tilt, displacement, load, and settlement. The measurements specified in this standard are as follows: ① Deflection measurements for buildings requiring deflection control in long-span structures; ② Axial shortening measurements of columns in high-rise buildings; ③ Crack measurements when cracks are suspected to be detrimental to structural safety; ④ Measurements of surrounding buildings when damage or potential damage occurs due to excavation, vibration, etc.; ⑤ Stress measurements of critical structural members experiencing high stress; ⑥ Strain measurements of major structural members in very important buildings. (4) If deemed necessary for safety management during construction other than that specified in (3), measurement management shall be performed through a separate measurement plan. 3. 9.2 Materials 3. 9. 2.1 Types of Measuring Instruments (1) The measurement error limit of measuring instruments for measuring settlement is ± 1.0mm or less. (2) When selecting instruments for inclination measurement, they shall be used in principle to measure the displacement of the building simultaneously by predicting the movement of the building in the X, Y, and Z three axes. (3) When using electrical resistance strain gauges for strain measurement, as they only measure the local displacement of the measurement target member, fiber optic gauges, long gages, laser gauges, etc. shall be used when measuring the widespread strain of structural members. (4) For crack measurement, economical and appropriate crack measurement methods and instruments shall be selected according to the required precision and purpose of crack measurement. (5) Instruments shall not be affected by external conditions such as temperature changes, corrosion, humidity, vibration, and electromagnetic interference. 3. 9.3 Construction 3. Nine. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) Slope Measurement ① The installation location of the instrumentation shall be selected to best represent the tilt of the target structure. ② When attaching the tilt plate, the base surface must be in a stable condition and should not be deformed by construction, temperature, humidity, or other factors. (2) Stress Measurement ① Instrumentation shall be installed on the main structural members of the target structure to identify the over-stress state of the structure. ② Load cells shall be installed during the construction process of the target structure. (3) Column Shortening Measurement ① The installation location of the instrumentation shall be on the main columns and core walls of the target structure. ② The column where the instrumentation is installed should have as few extraneous variables as possible, other than physical shortening, and should preferably be free from material defects such as cracks or voids. ③ The instrumentation shall be installed parallel to the axial direction of the column and at the center of the column or wall. 3. 9. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. (2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for any anomalies and calibrate if necessary. 3. 9. 3.3 Protection of Instruments (1) Installed instruments shall be protected from damage due to construction or other influences. 3. Nine. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) The installation of data transmission cables shall be in accordance with this standard. 3. 1. complies with 3.4 3. 9. 3.5 Inspection and testing following the installation of the measurement system (1) Inspection and testing following the installation of the measurement system shall be in accordance with this standard. 3. 1. follows 3.5 3. 9. 3.6 Management of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and the reliability of measurement results. (2) In the event that a measuring instrument is damaged, measurements shall continue after reinstalling the measuring instrument near the damaged one. (3) The installer of the measuring instrument shall take sufficient protective measures to prevent the loss of the measuring instrument until the purpose of the measurement is completed. 3. 9. 3.7 Performance of Instrumentation (1) Instrumentation and management shall be performed by the instrumentation dedicated team. (2) The instrumentation supervisor shall be a technical expert in the construction field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation equipment and the behavior of the target structure. (3) If long-term safety management is required due to various conditions, instrumentation equipment for this purpose shall be installed, and all related matters shall be transferred to the client in writing upon completion to ensure regular instrumentation during facility operation. (4) If errors occur in the instrumentation data or the reliability cannot be recognized due to damage or malfunction of the instrumentation during instrumentation, the initial value shall be re-established, and the correlation with previous instrumentation shall be determined in consultation with experts and supervisors. (5) Displacement measurements shall be divided into absolute displacement and relative displacement and performed in a direction appropriate for the measurement purpose. (6) When common crack and expansion factors such as temperature changes, groundwater level changes, and expansion due to load occur, simultaneous temperature measurements, groundwater level measurements, and other related instrumentation shall be performed or necessary data shall be secured. 3. Nine. 3.8 Instrumentation Frequency (1) The instrumentation frequency shall be determined considering the variability of applied loads, the failure/collapse modes of the structure, and the data resolution should be sufficient to fully understand the behavior of the building. (2) The frequency of instrumentation may be adjusted after confirmation by the construction supervisor, taking into account site conditions and ground conditions. (3) Settlement Measurement ① The instrumentation frequency of settlement gauges shall be conducted 2-3 times per week during the initial construction phase, and the frequency shall be gradually adjusted as the data stabilizes. ② Settlement measurements shall be performed every time a new floor is completed. (4) Strain Measurement ① The frequency of strain measurement shall be divided into regular and irregular measurements. ② Regular measurements shall be determined through consultation among the construction supervisor, designer, and related parties. ③ Irregular measurements shall be implemented at the discretion of the manager when sudden loads, such as wind or snow, are anticipated. (5) Column Reduction Measurement shall be performed at least every time a new floor is completed. 3. 9. 3.9 Instrumentation Period (1) The measurement period for settlement gauges shall be from the installation of the instrumentation to the point where convergence of displacement is confirmed. The convergence of the instrument shall be determined based on the amount of settlement over a specified period, defined as the relative settlement with respect to the absolute settlement or the total accumulated settlement. (2) The measurement period for inclinometers shall be from the installation of the instrumentation to the point where convergence of displacement is confirmed. The termination of inclination measurement shall be determined by reviewing the degree of convergence of related measurement results, such as borehole inclinometers, retaining wall inclinometers, and groundwater level gauges. (3) The measurement period for strain gauges shall be from the installation of the instrumentation to the completion of construction. 3. 9. 3.10 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results

(1) Settlement Measurement
① Prior to measurement, the management value shall be determined by considering the structural type, foundation type, importance of the structure, predicted settlement amount, etc., and approved by the site supervisor.
② If the absolute or relative settlement exceeds the management value, consult with an expert and take measures such as resetting the target value or ground reinforcement.

(2) Inclination Measurement
① If temporary removal of the instrument is unavoidable due to finishing or other construction work, final measurement shall be performed under the approval of the site supervisor, and the initial value shall be determined with reference to the previous data after reinstallation.
② When measuring the inclination of existing structures around the construction site, the condition of the existing structures shall be thoroughly investigated and analyzed.
③ When analyzing data, comprehensively review and analyze related measurement data such as piezometers, retaining wall inclinometers, and groundwater level gauges.

(3) Displacement Measurement
① Consider the effects of temperature changes, creep, or other external environmental factors, and analyze them concurrently with additional interpretations or related measurement results.
② The strength and modulus of elasticity of the target structure to be measured shall be verified through experiments or reliable data, and analysis shall be performed based on this.
③ Perform sag calculations through analysis before installing the instrument, and then analyze the measurement results.

(4) Strain Measurement
① Analyze the strain based on the strength and modulus of elasticity of the target structure to be measured, verified through experiments or reliable data.
② Observe the stress through the stress-strain relationship, and if the stress exceeds the yield strength, immediately stop construction and establish countermeasures.

(5) Crack Measurement
① Before crack measurement, an analysis of the cause of the crack, crack shape, stress condition, etc., regarding the crack to be measured must be performed first.
② Crack measurement shall simultaneously investigate and analyze changes in crack width and length.
③ Since cracks proceed differently depending on factors such as the material’s toughness and thickness, material properties should be considered during analysis.
④ When taking measures for cracks, consider the importance of the structure or structural member, material properties, crack pattern, and crack propagation trend.

(6) Column Shortening Measurement
① Calculate the result value as the average strain and analyze it considering creep after the measurement is performed.
② Perform reinterpretation or recalibration by regularly comparing the predicted shortening amount and the measured shortening amount.
③ Reinterpretation and recalibration shall be determined in consultation with the site supervisor before construction, and shall be performed basically at intervals of 10 to 20 floors. 3. 9. 3.11 Instrumentation Management Standards (1) The instrumentation management standards shall be determined in consultation with the on-site construction supervisor, taking into comprehensive consideration building factors such as the structural type, condition, and importance of the target structure, as well as member factors such as the material properties, structural mechanics conditions, and failure modes of the target structural members, as well as regional and environmental conditions. (2) Instrumentation management standards must be established prior to the commencement of instrumentation, and these standards may be amended or adjusted based on on-site conditions and circumstances if there is a justifiable reason, with the approval of relevant experts, the supervisory authority, and the management agency. 3. 9. "3.12 Measurement Result Report (1) The measurement result report is of this standard," 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. Nine. "3.13 Submission (1) The submission is of this standard." You shall submit the necessary documents in consultation with the construction supervisor, referring to 1.4. Underground excavation work 3. 1 0.1 General Provisions 3. 1 Zero. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of application of ground measurement during underground excavation construction shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. Following 1.1, this aims to ensure safety management during excavation work. (2) Matters not specified in (1) shall be governed by common convenience provisions, and matters not specified in the common convenience provisions shall be governed by the relevant design standards and standard specifications. 3. 1 0.2 Ingredients 3. 1 zero. 2.1 Types of Instrumentation (1) Inclinometers (also known as subsurface horizontal displacement gauges) are applied when the excavated ground is weak and ground displacement is anticipated, or when there are important structures within the range affected by the excavation work. (2) Ground water level meters are applied when changes in groundwater related to the excavation work are anticipated, and when there are important structures within the range affected by the excavation work. (3) Strain gauges are applied to stress-supporting components of retaining structures accompanying excavation work, such as support piles, H-piles, intermediate piles, tie-backs, and H-beams in composite sections. (4) Surface settlement gauges are applied when deep excavation and anticipated ground subsidence due to groundwater seepage, or when retaining walls are designed as flexible structures and subsidence of the backfill ground is anticipated due to wall displacement. (5) Extensometers are applied when excavating weak ground adjacent to buried important underground structures. (6) Tiltmeters are applied to measure the tilt change of buildings or structures located within the range affected by ground displacement caused by excavation work, which is attributed to differential settlement. (7) Crack meters are applied to measure changes in cracks that have occurred in buildings or structures located within the range affected by ground displacement caused by excavation work. 3. 1 Zero. 2.2 Data Acquisition System (1) The data acquisition system shall be configured considering factors such as ease of measurement, measurement frequency, measurement method, device compatibility, and cost-effectiveness. (2) Operation techniques for measurement instruments can be broadly divided into manual operation and automated operation using automated equipment, and the operation technique should be selected considering factors such as the characteristics of collapse and activity progression, the importance of the measured facility, the impact of damage, cost-effectiveness, and measurement frequency. 3. 1 0.3 construction 3. 1 zero. 3.1 Installation of Monitoring Instruments (1) Monitoring instruments installed outside the excavation site shall be installed and completed before excavation, and initial readings shall be taken before the excavation impacts the measurement location. Monitoring instruments installed within the excavation site shall be installed immediately after excavation or immediately after the installation of temporary supports, and initial readings shall be taken immediately. (2) The installation location of the borehole horizontal displacement gauge (borehole inclinometer) ① shall be approximately from the thumb pin or wall of the area where a critical structure is located behind the excavation. The work area should be located with a sufficient clearance of approximately 0.5m to allow for easy access. ② The borehole diameter for the underground inclination control system installation shall be large enough to accommodate the insertion of the system’s pipes and subsequent grouting. ③ When a grouting pipe is inserted separately from the underground inclination control system pipe, the borehole diameter shall be large enough to accommodate the insertion of both the system pipe and the grouting pipe. If a grouting pipe is not required, the space outside the system pipe shall be sufficiently large to allow the grouting backfill material to pass through easily. ④ During drilling, if there is a concern about the collapse of the borehole wall in a specific layer, casing shall be used to protect the borehole wall. ⑤ The drilling depth shall be within a stable ground layer, where ground displacement is considered negligible, to serve as a reference for measuring horizontal displacement. "1.5m or higher. ⑥ The joints of the inclinometer pipes shall be sealed with silicone and tape, etc., after riveting to prevent the grouting filler material from entering. ⑦ When measuring with an inclinometer, sufficient grouting filler and an appropriate curing period shall be provided to ensure the reliability of the initial readings and to prevent the inclinometer from swaying. ⑧ If the retaining wall is a buried continuous wall, an inclinometer shall be installed inside the wall to directly measure the wall’s deformation due to excavation, and if movement of the bottom of the wall is a concern, additional borehole drilling below the bottom of the wall should also be considered through this installation pipe. (3) Piezometer ① The location selection and installation of drilling equipment shall be based on the horizontal displacement measurement instrument. ② At the lowest point inside the borehole" 1. A permeable layer shall be formed by filling with sand or gravel of good grading to a depth of approximately 0.5m, and care shall be taken to prevent air voids from forming due to excessively large grain size during permeable layer formation. ③ Backfill material shall be filled with soil similar to the original ground in terms of permeability. ④ In the event of damage to upper and lower utilities around the instrumentation, the drop in water level due to excavation cannot be accurately determined, so the distance between the instrumentation and the utilities, and the size of the utilities, shall be recorded to assess the degree of influence. ⑤ The position of relocated cable trays due to excavation process shall be measured and arranged in a single row at regular intervals to predict the influence distance and possibility of damage. (4) Strain gauges ① Select and install an appropriate size and type for the intended purpose (resistive, V.W. type, buried, surface-mounted). ② Install them to align with the desired measurement direction and firmly bond them to the member to ensure integration. ③ Since strain gauges installed on steel structures may be degraded by high voltage, ensure that the wires do not directly contact the steel structure. ④ When extending the cable from the installation point to the measurement point, perform a complete joint to prevent accurate connection, waterproofing, and damage to the connection point. (5) Surface settlement gauges ① Shall simultaneously satisfy the arrangement in the direction parallel to the retaining wall and the arrangement in the direction perpendicular to the retaining wall. ② Survey control points shall be secured at immovable locations. If securing a fixed point in the field is difficult, a ground rod may be buried in the ground to install a fixed point. (6) In-ground settlement gauges ① Determine the borehole depth according to the installation location of the important structure and drill a borehole. ② Insert the sensor into the borehole by attaching the desired number of sensors to the outside of the casing. ③ Grouting shall be performed in the borehole. ④ The casing shall be inserted only to the depth where the boring pile does not stand alone, and after the installation of the instrument is completed, it must be removed. ⑤ The initial value shall be measured after the grouting of the borehole has been cured. (7) Building inclinometers ① Orient the 1-axis of the Tiltmeter plate’s 1-axis to 3-axis towards the field direction and adjust to maintain level. (8) Crack gauges ① Crack measurements of adjacent buildings or structures located within the influence range of the excavation work shall be performed before construction to secure initial values, and confirmation shall be obtained from the building owner. ② In addition to the measuring instruments, crack measurements shall be recorded as evidence by taking photographs or videos. 3. 1 zero. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for operability before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. 3. 1 Zero. 3.3 Protection of Instrumentation (1) If any part of the instrumentation is exposed after installation, it shall be protected by appropriate protective devices to prevent damage from construction equipment or personnel, and a sign shall be installed in a conspicuous location. (2) After grouting is completed, a lid shall be installed on top of the measurement well for horizontal displacement gauges to prevent the entry of debris such as soil or stones. (3) For groundwater level gauges and ground settlement gauges, if there is a possibility of surface water or rainwater entering from the ground surface to the top of the measurement well, concrete or mortar shall be applied around the well to prevent the inflow of surface water, and the upper part of the borehole shall be completely sealed. (4) After the instrument benchmark concrete has hardened, a protective cover shall be placed over the surface settlement gauge. 3. 1 Zero. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Cables for transmitting measurement data shall select a format suitable for continuous measurement and establish an installation plan including cable laying, communication standards, and cable connection and termination. (2) Measurement instrument cables shall use dedicated measurement instrument cables, and during installation, they shall be configured as a single run without any connection points from the buried location to the measurement room. (3) Wiring for all measurement instruments shall be protected by installing measurement-dedicated conduits. 3. 1 Zero. 3.5 Inspection and Testing Following Instrumentation System Installation (1) After completing adjustment and testing of the instrumentation system installation work, the following commissioning tests shall be performed. ① The instrumentation equipment installation responsible engineer shall be responsible for the primary commissioning of the equipment under no-load conditions and shall prepare and submit a test report to the construction supervisor after completion of the test. ② Comprehensive commissioning shall be a commissioning test under load conditions, including comprehensive commissioning of other equipment related to this equipment, to verify overall functionality. 3. 1 zero. 3.6 Management of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to maintain performance and ensure the reliability of measurement results. (2) Instruction labels and nameplates shall be attached to measuring instruments and data acquisition devices. 3. 1 zero. 3.7 Instrumentation Implementation (1) Instrumentation and monitoring shall be performed by the dedicated instrumentation team. (2) The instrumentation supervisor shall be a top-grade technician in the construction field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation equipment and the behavior of the ground and temporary structures affected by the excavation work. (3) Strain gauges for support shall be measured once before and after jack pressure after support installation, and the difference due to jack pressure shall be identified. Displacement gauges for bracings shall also be measured before and after jack pressure, and the difference in displacement due to jack pressure shall be recorded. (4) Strain gauges for sheet piles shall be measured once before and after jack pressure when the supporting structure is a support, and once before and after tensioning when the supporting structure is an anchor, and the change due to tension shall be recorded. (5) Surface settlement measurements shall be recorded using a LEVEL after performing three or more repeated measurements. (6) If the tiltmeter readings are unstable and moving slightly, repeat measurements 2-3 times. 3. 1 zero. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) The measurement frequency shall be determined by classifying elements based on whether or not they are susceptible to collapse. (2) Real-time measurements shall be conducted during the real-time application of additional loads to elements susceptible to collapse, and the standard measurement frequency shall be applied to elements not susceptible to collapse. 3. 1 Zero. 3.9 Monitoring Period (1) The monitoring period shall be from the installation of the measuring instruments until the completion of the underground structure and backfilling. (2) The monitoring period for measuring instruments for support shall be from the installation of the measuring instruments until the removal of the support. 3. 1 zero. 3.10 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) The measurement record sheet shall specify the soil composition, presence and removal of retaining structures, type of retaining wall, proximity of adjacent structures, architectural style of adjacent structures, degree of aging, foundation type and depth, etc. (2) Measurement results shall be represented graphically showing changes in measurement values over time, and the time-series change graph shall record the groundwater level, current excavation depth and corresponding management criteria, presence and removal of support structures, and measurement temperature. (3) The measurement results of the inclinometer shall be analyzed with time-series change graphs for each depth, along with the management criteria for the excavation depth at the time of measurement. (4) In the graph of measurement value changes over time for each depth, if displacement increases or abnormal displacement occurs without excavation progress, the on-site conditions shall be carefully observed to verify the cause and establish countermeasures before proceeding with excavation, and a report shall be submitted. (5) Measurement results shall be comprehensively analyzed by combining the measurement results of various instruments installed in a section of the entire excavation area, such as inclinometers, load cells, strain gauges, displacement gauges, ground settlement gauges, structural tilt gauges, crack gauges, and vibration gauges, to determine the stability of the retaining structure at that section, and the analysis results shall be reported to the site supervisor. 3. 1 Zero. 3.11 Instrumentation Management Criteria (1) Instrumentation management criteria are determined by factors such as ground behavior, dynamic conditions of retaining structures and earth pressure, and safety limits of adjacent structures. Therefore, it is difficult to present clear standard values, so they should be based on design expected values, taking into account site conditions. (2) For stress measurement instruments, structural analysis and laboratory tests considering the load conditions at the time of instrument installation should be performed to determine the management criteria. (3) For various displacement gauges, crack gauges, groundwater level gauges, etc., instrumentation management criteria should be established after confirming the initial values, and the method for setting the initial values should be specified in detail. (4) Management criteria for ground inclination gauges can be determined with reference to the following values. ① Ground inclination gauges should establish allowable limits based on design expected values, considering the degree of deformation of the retaining wall according to the stiffness of the retaining wall, the characteristics of the excavated ground, the excavation depth, the support structure, and countermeasures against groundwater. ② Setting the maximum displacement based on the stiffness of the retaining wall and the excavation depth (H) is the easiest method; however, if these values exceed the design expected values, setting the design expected values as the management criteria is desirable. Typical maximum allowable displacement is as follows. a. Stiff retaining walls (continuous concrete walls with t ≥ 60cm): Approximately 0.002H (H: excavation depth). Typically, retaining walls (continuous concrete walls with a thickness of approximately 40cm): "It is 0.0025H (H: excavation depth). Flexible retaining wall (retaining wall installed with H-Piles and sheet piles):" 0.003H (H: excavation depth) ③ To prevent cracking of adjacent ground, the daily maximum variation in displacement should be referenced to the following allowable criteria, but should not exceed the design expected value. a. δ ≤ 2mm (7 days): conservatively b. 2mm c. 4mm d. 10mm ④ The daily abnormal displacement criteria for checking rock sliding or loosening of ground anchor anchorages are as follows. a. δ ≤ 1mm (1 day): conservatively b. 1mm c. 2mm d. 4mm ⑤ Since the above management criteria may be unsuitable depending on field conditions or the error of measuring instruments, continuous measurements should be performed, and the management criteria values should be supplemented to match the field conditions according to the excavation stage. ⑥ Wall deformation should be determined based on the estimated values at the design stage. (F(5) The management criteria for the groundwater level gauge can be determined as follows. ① The setting of management criteria should be based on field conditions and excavation conditions rather than the design stage. ② In the event of a rapid drop in groundwater level, excavation should be stopped immediately to check the integrity of the retaining wall and the amount of backfill ground settlement. After that, excavation work may be resumed after the water level recovers to the original level or if no abnormalities are found. (6) The management criteria for the building tiltmeter should be based on the limit of each displacement affecting the structure and the damage limit of the structure according to the type of structural foundation. 3. 1 Zero. 3.12 Measurement Result Reporting (1) Measurement data shall be organized immediately after the measurement is performed. On-site data shall be immediately analyzed, considering factors such as construction progress and weather conditions, and visualized through charts, etc. Various measurement results shall be analyzed in conjunction with each other, and if any abnormal signs are detected when compared with predicted values, they shall be immediately reported to the contractor and the construction supervisor. (2) Matters concerning measurement result reporting other than (1) shall be in accordance with this standard. 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. 1 Zero.
