Blasting Vibration Induction Construction 3. 1 General Provisions 3. 1 1. 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The instrumentation management of blasting vibration-inducing work aims to ensure safety during blasting operations conducted as part of various construction projects. (2) Blasting work instrumentation management is divided into initial blasting instrumentation management, carried out at the commencement of blasting work, and continuous instrumentation management conducted on security facilities within the range of influence of blasting during blasting work. 3. 1 1.2 Ingredients: None 3. 1 1.3 Construction 3. 1 1. 3.1 Installation of Measuring Instruments (1) The measuring instruments shall be installed accurately according to the procedures specified in the manufacturer's instructions. (2) Installation of Blasting Vibration Measuring Devices ① Installation methods according to vibration acceleration are as follows. a. The ground conditions in the area where the vibration gauge is located, such as sand, uncompacted soil, flower beds, or straw, may affect the accuracy of the records, so the ground conditions shall be checked. b. The vibration gauge should be installed as horizontally as possible, based on its operating principle. c. The travel direction component of the vibration gauge shall be installed so that it always aligns with the direction indicator on the measuring instrument and the direction of the blasting source. d. Vibration acceleration. If the acceleration is 0.2g or less, embedment or attachment is not required.마. 진동가속도가 0.2g and When the range is between 1.0g, embedding or attachment is preferable, and it is good to fix the vibration gauge by driving it in with spikes. Also, if the spike of the instrument does not penetrate the ground, cover the instrument completely with sandbags to apply a load so that it moves together with the ground. B. Vibration acceleration... 1. If the weight exceeds 1.0g, burial or secure attachment is required. ② Attachment or burial methods shall follow the following: a. The burial depth shall not exceed three times the height of the instrument, and the instrument shall be placed in a vinyl bag at the bottom and buried, or the instrument shall be driven into the ground using spikes attached to the instrument, and the surrounding and top of the instrument shall be firmly compacted with soil. b. In cases where installation is required in locations such as very hard ground, concrete structures, and bedrock, fix it using a fixing plate with bolts or anchors, or adhere it to the bedrock surface or ground using gypsum, cement mortar, double-sided tape, epoxy resin, rubber clay, or mud. c. If the foundation of the structure is located within ±30mm of the ground surface, the instrument can be attached to the structure's foundation. However, this method should only be used when burial, spiking, or covering with sandbags is difficult. ③ Other installation methods are as follows: a. When fixing with spikes, remove the stake while minimizing soil disturbance, and ensure that the instrument attached to the spike is firmly pressed against the ground. b. If the instrument’s spikes cannot be inserted into the ground, use sandbags. The sandbags should be sufficiently large and loosely filled with sand weighing approximately 50N~120N, and should be covered evenly with a low and wide vertical cross-section to maximize contact with the ground, applying a load to the instrument so that it behaves as if it were part of the ground. (3) Installation of blasting noise (overpressure) measurement device ① When buildings, automobiles, or other obstacles are located near the measurement point, the sound level meter microphone should be installed so that the blasting wind from the blasting is not interfered with by these obstacles. However, if these obstacles cannot be avoided, the horizontal distance between the obstacle and the sound level meter microphone should be greater than the height of the obstacle above the microphone. ② If installed too close to a structure, overpressure can be reflected from the building surface and amplified, so the sound level meter should be installed as close to a corner as possible to minimize reverberation caused by the structure. ③ To reduce the influence of wind, attach a wind screen provided by the manufacturer to the instrument. 3. 1 1. 3.2 Calibration of Measuring Instruments
(1) Measuring instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary.
(2) If the measured values change abnormally during measurement, check the measuring instrument for malfunctions and calibrate if necessary.
(3) Measuring instruments that have been in use for over one year or have been frequently measured shall be calibrated annually.
(4) Blasting Vibration Measurement
① The ground vibration trigger level shall be set in consideration of the expected vibration velocity according to the measurement purpose. Generally, the trigger level is set based on ground vibration or overpressure, but it is generally set based on vibration.
② The resolution of the recorded waveform shall be sufficient to verify whether the measured waveform is caused by blasting or not.
③ The vibration recording time shall be input in consideration of the speed of sound, the distance from the blasting point, and the blasting duration. Generally, it is set to a minimum of 2 seconds longer than the blasting vibration duration, and an additional 1 second is added for every 300m from the blasting point.
④ Note that in controlled blasting, the time setting should be higher than the maximum blasting delay time.
(5) Blasting Noise (Overpressure) Measurement
① To minimize malfunctions caused by erroneous noise, measure the ambient noise level in advance and set the trigger level higher than that level.
② When only overpressure measurement is required, set the trigger level sufficiently low to match the overpressure.
③ When only overpressure is measured, set the recording time longer than the blasting duration. If ground vibration and overpressure are recorded simultaneously, follow the ground vibration setting guidelines. 3. 1 1. 3.3 Management of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures provided by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and the reliability of measurement results. (2) When making measurements manually, manage to minimize conditions that may cause vibration and noise at the measurement point. (3) When making measurements automatically, attach a sign indicating that the instrument is being used and select a location as far away from the instrument as possible. 3. 1 1. 3.4 Instrumentation Implementation (1) The person responsible for instrumentation shall be a first-class technician in the construction-related field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation and the impact of blasting noise. (2) Instrumentation implementation shall be performed by a specialized engineering company related to blasting, to accumulate objective data to verify the safety of surrounding protected objects and prepare for future blasting-related complaints. (3) Blasting vibration and blasting noise (overpressure) shall be measured in accordance with the measurement method for each measurement item. (4) For instrumentation implementation during trial blasting, the following shall be observed. ① Since the purpose is to identify the propagation characteristics of the ground during trial blasting and obtain an on-site vibration estimation formula for blasting impact analysis, the instruments should be arranged as straight as possible, at equal intervals, and towards the main protected objects. ② To obtain the best damping relationship, measurement lines shall be established and equipment arranged in areas with uniform geological conditions. ③ Measurements shall, in principle, simultaneously measure the three components: vertical (V: Vertical), longitudinal (L: Longitudinal), and transverse (T: Transverse). ④ To perform quantitative analysis of the trial blasting, a statistically significant number of measurement data are required, and the number of blasting times and the number of installed instruments shall be planned to obtain at least 30 measurement points to increase reliability. ⑤ The instrumentation shall be securely fixed on the ground or on a structure so that it can move together with the ground movement, and in the case of hard ground, it shall be firmly installed in the ground using spikes attached to the instrumentation. ⑥ The installation direction of the instrumentation shall always match the direction indicator marked on the instrumentation and the direction of the blast source, and the measurements shall be performed accordingly. 3. 1 1. 3.5 Measurement Frequency (1) When excavation is performed by blasting, measurements of vibration and noise shall be carried out for each blast. (2) When excavation is performed by machinery, measurements shall be taken at a frequency of 2 to 3 times per day. 3. 1 1. 3.6 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) Measurement results shall be analyzed by technicians experienced in blasting and with an understanding of the characteristics of blasting noise. (2) Record the measurement results in the record sheet, including project name, location, date, construction company, and measurement company. (3) If the measurement analysis results indicate any adverse effects on the surrounding area, appropriate measures shall be taken, the cause shall be identified, and subsequent blasting operations shall be performed. (4) Upon completion of the measurement, compile the measurement results and submit them to the construction supervisor for confirmation before proceeding with subsequent work. (5) Details of the measurement result analysis are as follows. ① For quantitative regression analysis, it is the principle to conduct test blasting patterns with varying drilling and blasting quantities. However, if a single pattern is applied, consider varying the measurement distance to obtain various scaled distances. ② The number of analysis points shall be analyzed using a minimum of 30 or more measurement data. ③ The measured data shall be statistically processed using a regression analysis technique, with the input data based on the maximum particle velocity (PPV: Peak Particle Velocity) of each component. ④ Regression analysis shall be performed using square root scaled distance and cube root scaled distance, applying the estimation equation with the highest goodness of fit. ⑤ The blasting vibration estimation equation produced after regression analysis shall apply a confidence level of 95%. ⑥ The correlation coefficient of the measurement result estimation equation... If the value is less than 0.70, a trial blasting shall be repeated. 3. 1 1. 3.7 Instrumentation Management Criteria (1) Quantitative limits are needed as a basis for analyzing and evaluating blasting vibrations, but since these vary depending on the material, structure, and foundation of the structure, as well as the angle and frequency of the vibration wave, there are no legal regulatory standards in Korea, and they are applied flexibly by each client. Therefore, experts should establish site-specific blasting vibration allowable limits, referring to the existing blasting vibration standards and background, and the results of trial blasting. (2) When setting blasting vibration limits, a detailed understanding of the condition and status of security assets is necessary, and the blasting vibration limits should be proposed, categorized into blasting work safety management criteria, blasting vibration allowable criteria, and blasting vibration limit criteria. ① Blasting work safety management criteria: Criteria to ensure complete safety, taking into account the uncertainties of blasting work. ② Blasting vibration allowable criteria: Criteria under which no damage occurs to nearby security assets in practice. ③ Blasting vibration limit criteria: The minimum limit at which even minor damage can be caused to security assets. (3) Blasting vibration values are based on the maximum value of each component (PPV: Peak Particle Velocity). You shall submit the necessary documents by consulting with the construction supervisor, referring to 1.4. 3.12 Temporary Bracing and Scaffolding Works 3. 1 2.1 General Provisions 3. 1 2. 1. General 1.1 Scope of Application (1) The scope of ground measurement during the construction of temporary screens and scaffolding shall be in accordance with Section 1, General, of this standard. "1.1 shall apply to temporary structures such as formwork and scaffolding installed for the construction of structures. (2) Measurement management for purposes other than those specified in (1) shall be performed separately." 3. 1 2.2 Materials 3. 1 2. 2.1 Types of Measuring Instruments (1) Load cells shall have a capacity of 200% or more of the maximum load they are designed to measure. (2) Displacement gauges shall meet a precision of 1/100mm or less. (3) Strain gauges shall be products suitable for the installation conditions. (4) The precision of inclinometers shall be based on 1mm. 3. 1 2. 2.2 Data Acquisition System (1) Automated or semi-automated operating techniques shall be selected, considering the conditions of the measurement target. (2) In the case of formwork for concrete pouring, since loads are concentrated during concrete pouring, it is important to detect signs early and promptly transmit and process the information simultaneously with monitoring. Therefore, automated technology that consistently handles real-time data acquisition, processing, and interpretation should be employed as a principle. 3. 1 2.3 Construction 3. 1 2. 3.1 Instrumentation Installation (1) All instrumentation to be installed on temporary structures shall be completed before excavation or the installation of the temporary structures, and initial readings shall be taken before any load acting on the temporary structure affects the measurement location. (2) Instrumentation for elements difficult to install in an unfinished construction stage shall be installed after the target temporary structure is in place and before proceeding to the next construction stage. 3. 1 2. 3.2 Calibration of Instruments (1) Instruments shall be inspected for functionality before and immediately after installation, and calibrated if necessary. 3. 1 2. 3.3 Protection of Instruments (1) Installed instruments shall be protected from damage due to construction or other influences. 3. 1 2. 3.4 Data Transmission Cable Installation (1) Instrument cables shall use instrument-dedicated cables, and during installation, they shall be configured as a single run from the buried point to the measurement room without any connection points. 3. 1 2. After the installation and adjustment of measuring instruments, completion tests shall be conducted, and a commissioning test shall be performed. 3. 1 2. 3.6 Management of Measuring Instruments (1) Measuring instruments shall be managed in accordance with the methods and procedures specified by the manufacturer to ensure performance preservation and the reliability of measurement results. (2) Measuring instruments and data acquisition devices shall be affixed with instruction labels and nameplates. (3) Installed measuring instruments shall be managed with a display panel indicating the instrument name, location, initial measurement date, and initial measurement value. 3. 1 2. 3.7 Performance of Instrumentation (1) When load changes continuously over time, real-time instrumentation shall be performed during the time the load is reapplied, and the measurement results shall be reviewed and reported to the site supervisor for necessary actions. (2) The performance and management of instrumentation can be carried out either by the contractor or maintenance entity directly operating an in-house instrumentation team or by entrusting it to a specialized instrumentation company. (3) The instrumentation manager shall be a first-class technician in the construction-related field who understands the characteristics of the instrumentation and the behavior of the member to which the instrumentation is attached. 3. 1 2. 3.8 Measurement Frequency (1) When the load on the temporary support changes over time, measurements shall be taken in real-time. (2) For temporary support structures where the real-time load does not change, real-time measurements are not required. 3. 1 2. 3.9 Measurement Period (1) The measurement period shall be based on the period from the installation of the measurement equipment until the convergence of the measured values is confirmed. 3. 1 2. 3.10 Summary and Analysis of Measurement Results (1) Measurement results should be organized immediately after the measurement is performed. (2) In the case of real-time measurement, the measurement personnel shall monitor the real-time measurement results and analyze the absolute change and rate of change to determine the risk of the measured object. 3. 1 2. 3.11 Instrumentation Management Standards (1) The instrumentation management standards shall be determined based on the properties of the materials, and the reference values shall be determined with reference to the design expected values in the structural calculation. (2) During the instrumentation period, the instrumentation management standard values shall be determined separately for persistence and abruptness, referring to factors such as the absolute change amount and rate of change. 3. 1 2. 3.12 Measurement Result Reporting (1) When real-time measurement is performed, the measurement personnel shall monitor the real-time measurement results and analyze the absolute change and rate of change. If they determine that the measured member is unsuitable for supporting the required load and is unstable, they shall immediately report this to the site supervisor, who may instruct the contractor to suspend subsequent work. (2) Matters regarding measurement result reporting other than (1) shall be in accordance with this standard. 3. 1. follows 3.12 3. 1 2. Submission 3.13 (1) The submission is based on this standard. You shall submit the necessary documents by consulting with the construction supervisor with reference to 1.4.
